article1.question: According to Article 1, Section 1 of the Texas Constitution, Texas is a free and independent State, subject only to what?
article1.answer: The Constitution of the United States
options: The laws passed by the Texas Legislature
The will of the people of Texas
The Constitution of the United States
article1.reference: Sec. 1. FREEDOM AND SOVEREIGNTY OF STATE. Texas is a free and independent State, subject only to the Constitution of the United States...

article1.question: Article 1, Section 2 states that all political power is inherent in what group, and all free governments are founded on their authority?
article1.answer: The people
article1.reference: Sec. 2. INHERENT POLITICAL POWER; REPUBLICAN FORM OF GOVERNMENT. All political power is inherent in the people, and all free governments are founded on their authority, and instituted for their benefit.

article1.question: The faith of the people of Texas stands pledged to the preservation of what form of government?
article1.answer: A republican form of government
article1.reference: The faith of the people of Texas stands pledged to the preservation of a republican form of government...

article1.question: Article 1, Section 3a prohibits the denial or abridgment of equality under the law because of what?
article1.answer: Sex, race, color, creed, or national origin.
options: Sex, race, color, creed, or national origin.
article1.reference: Sec. 3a. EQUALITY UNDER THE LAW. Equality under the law shall not be denied or abridged because of sex, race, color, creed, or national origin.

article1.question: What does Article 1, Section 4 of the Texas Constitution prohibit?
article1.answer: Requiring any religious test as a qualification for any office or public trust.
options: The establishment of a state religion.
Requiring any religious test as a qualification for any office or public trust.
Holding public office if you are an atheist.
article1.reference: Sec. 4. RELIGIOUS TESTS. No religious test shall ever be required as a qualification to any office, or public trust, in this State...

article1.question: While no religious test can be required for public office, what must a person in office acknowledge, according to Section 4?
article1.answer: The existence of a Supreme Being.
options: The separation of church and state.
The existence of a Supreme Being.
The supremacy of the Texas Constitution.
article1.reference: ...nor shall any one be excluded from holding office on account of his religious sentiments, provided he acknowledge the existence of a Supreme Being.

article1.question: Under Article 1, Section 5, a person is not disqualified from giving evidence on account of what?
article1.answer: His religious opinions.
options: His personal interest in the case.
article1.reference: Sec. 5. WITNESSES NOT DISQUALIFIED BY RELIGIOUS BELIEFS; OATHS AND AFFIRMATIONS. No person shall be disqualified to give evidence in any of the Courts of this State on account of his religious opinions...

article1.question: According to Article 1, Section 6, no human authority ought to control or interfere with what?
article1.answer: The rights of conscience in matters of religion.
options: The rights of conscience in matters of religion.
The right to a public education.
article1.reference: No human authority ought, in any case whatever, to control or interfere with the rights of conscience in matters of religion...

article1.question: In a prosecution for libel (the publication of papers investigating public officials), what can be given in evidence?
article1.answer: The truth of the matter.
options: The political affiliation of the official.
The number of people who read the paper.
article1.reference: Sec. 8. FREEDOM OF SPEECH AND PRESS; LIBEL...and in all indictments for libels, the jury shall have the right to determine the law and the facts, under the direction of the Court, as in other cases.

article1.question: According to Article 1, Section 9, a warrant to search a place or seize a person must be based on what?
article1.answer: Probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation.
options: The general reputation of the person.
Probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation.
article1.reference: ...and no warrant to search any place, or to seize any person or thing, shall issue without describing them as near as may be, nor without probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation.

article1.question: Which of the following is a right of the accused in a criminal prosecution, according to Article 1, Section 10?
article1.answer: The right to be heard by himself or counsel, or both.
options: The right to a private trial.
The right to choose the judge presiding over the case.
The right to be heard by himself or counsel, or both.
The right to delay the trial indefinitely.
article1.reference: In all criminal prosecutions the accused shall have a speedy public trial by an impartial jury. He shall have the right to demand the nature and cause of the accusation against him, and to have a copy thereof. He shall not be compelled to give evidence against himself, and shall have the right of being heard by himself or counsel, or both...

article1.question: Article 1, Section 10, states that an accused shall not be compelled to do what?
article1.answer: Give evidence against himself.
options: Pay for court costs if found not guilty.
article1.reference: He shall not be compelled to give evidence against himself, and shall have the right of being heard by himself or counsel, or both...

article1.question: When can bail be denied for a felony less than capital, according to Section 11a?
article1.answer: When the person has been theretofore twice convicted of a felony.
options: If the person is a flight risk.
When the person has one prior felony conviction.
When the person has been theretofore twice convicted of a felony.
article1.reference: Sec. 11a. MULTIPLE CONVICTIONS; DENIAL OF BAIL. (a) Any person (1) accused of a felony less than capital in this State, who has been theretofore twice convicted of a felony...

article1.question: What is the writ of Habeas Corpus defined as in Article 1, Section 12?
article1.answer: A writ of right.
article1.reference: Sec. 12. HABEAS CORPUS. The writ of Habeas Corpus is a writ of right, and shall never be suspended.

article1.question: Article 1, Section 13, ensures that all courts shall be what?
article1.answer: Open.
article1.reference: All courts shall be open, and every person for an injury done him, in his lands, goods, person or reputation, shall have remedy by due course of law.

article1.question: What does Article 1, Section 14 prohibit?
article1.answer: Double Jeopardy.
article1.reference: Sec. 14. DOUBLE JEOPARDY. No person, for the same offense, shall be twice put in jeopardy of life or liberty...

article1.question: Article 1, Section 15-a provides for the commitment of persons of unsound mind to custody for what purpose?
article1.answer: For their restraint and care.
article1.reference: Sec. 15-a. COMMITMENT OF PERSONS OF UNSOUND MIND. No person shall be committed as a person of unsound mind except on competent medical or psychiatric testimony. The Legislature may enact all laws necessary to provide for the trial, adjudication of insanity and commitment of persons of unsound mind and to provide for a method of appeal from judgments rendered in such cases.

article1.question: What is an 'ex post facto law,' which is prohibited by Article 1, Section 16?
article1.answer: A law that retroactively makes a previously legal act a criminal offense.
options: A law that impairs the obligation of contracts.
A legislative act that declares someone guilty without a trial.
A law that applies to future actions only.
A law that retroactively makes a previously legal act a criminal offense.
article1.reference: Sec. 16. BILLS OF ATTAINDER; EX POST FACTO OR RETROACTIVE LAWS; IMPAIRING OBLIGATION OF CONTRACTS. No bill of attainder, ex post facto law, retroactive law, or any law impairing the obligation of contracts, shall be made.

article1.question: What does Article 1, Section 18 state about imprisonment for debt?
article1.answer: No person shall ever be imprisoned for debt.
options: A person can be imprisoned for debts owed to the State.
A person can be imprisoned for debt if fraud is involved.
No person shall ever be imprisoned for debt.
A person can be imprisoned for debt if the amount is over $1,000,000.
article1.reference: Sec. 18. IMPRISONMENT FOR DEBT. No person shall ever be imprisoned for debt.

article1.question: According to Article 1, Section 22, what is required to convict a person of treason?
article1.answer: The testimony of two witnesses to the same overt act, or confession in open court.
options: The testimony of two witnesses to the same overt act, or confession in open court.
article1.reference: Sec. 22. TREASON. Treason against the State shall consist only in levying war against it, or adhering to its enemies, giving them aid and comfort; and no person shall be convicted of treason except on the testimony of two witnesses to the same overt act, or on confession in open court.

article1.question: Article 1, Section 25, places a restriction on the quartering of soldiers in a house. What is that restriction?
article1.answer: No soldier shall in time of peace be quartered in the house of any citizen without the consent of the owner.
options: Soldiers may be quartered if they pay rent.
No soldier shall in time of peace be quartered in the house of any citizen without the consent of the owner.
Soldiers can be quartered in any house during wartime.
A homeowner can be forced to quarter soldiers if ordered by a general.
article1.reference: Sec. 25. QUARTERING SOLDIERS IN HOUSES. No soldier shall in time of peace be quartered in the house of any citizen without the consent of the owner, nor in time of war but in a manner prescribed by law.

article1.question: What does Article 1, Section 26 declare to be contrary to the genius of a free government?
article1.answer: Perpetuities and monopolies.
article1.reference: Sec. 26. PERPETUITIES AND MONOPOLIES; PRIMOGENITURE OR ENTAILMENTS. Perpetuities and monopolies are contrary to the genius of a free government, and shall never be allowed...

article1.question: What does Article 1, Section 29 state about the Bill of Rights?
article1.answer: That everything in the Bill of Rights is excepted out of the general powers of government and shall forever remain inviolate.
options: That the Bill of Rights can be amended by a simple majority vote.
That the Legislature can suspend parts of the Bill of Rights.
That the Bill of Rights is a guide, but not legally binding.
That everything in the Bill of Rights is excepted out of the general powers of government and shall forever remain inviolate.
article1.reference: Sec. 29. PROVISIONS OF BILL OF RIGHTS EXCEPTED FROM POWERS OF GOVERNMENT; TO FOREVER REMAIN INVIOLATE. To guard against transgressions of the high powers herein delegated, we declare that every thing in this 'Bill of Rights' is excepted out of the general powers of government, and shall forever remain inviolate...

article1.question: What right does Article 1, Section 30 grant to a crime victim regarding court proceedings?
article1.answer: The right to be present at all public court proceedings related to the offense.
options: The right to act as their own prosecutor.
The right to be present at all public court proceedings related to the offense.
The right to have the trial moved to their home county.
The right to cross-examine the defendant.
article1.reference: Sec. 30. RIGHTS OF CRIME VICTIMS. (a) A crime victim has the following rights: ... (3) the right to be present at all public court proceedings related to the offense, unless the victim is to testify and the court determines that the victim's testimony would be materially affected if the victim hears other testimony at the trial.

article1.question: What is the subject of Article 1, Section 34 of the Texas Constitution?
article1.answer: The right to hunt, fish, and harvest wildlife.
options: The right to access public beaches.
The right to hunt, fish, and harvest wildlife.
The rights of facility residents to designate a caregiver.
article1.reference: Sec. 34. RIGHT TO HUNT, FISH, AND HARVEST WILDLIFE. (a) The people have the right to hunt, fish, and harvest wildlife...

article1.question: Article 1, Section 36 establishes a right for landowners and lessees to engage in what generally accepted practices?
article1.answer: Farming, ranching, timber production, horticulture, and wildlife management.
options: Mining, oil drilling, and mineral exploration.
Farming, ranching, timber production, horticulture, and wildlife management.
article1.reference: Sec. 36. RIGHT TO ENGAGE IN FARMING, RANCHING, TIMBER PRODUCTION, HORTICULTURE, AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. (a) The people have the right to engage in generally accepted farm, ranch, timber production, horticulture, or wildlife management practices on real property they own or lease.

article3.question: According to Article 3, Section 1 of the Texas Constitution, where is the Legislative power of the State vested?
article3.answer: In a Senate and House of Representatives.
options: In a Senate and House of Representatives.
In the People of Texas directly.
article3.reference: Sec. 1. SENATE AND HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. The Legislative power of this State shall be vested in a Senate and House of Representatives, which together shall be styled 'The Legislature of the State of Texas.'

article3.question: How many members does the Texas Senate consist of?
article3.reference: Sec. 2. MEMBERSHIP OF SENATE AND HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. The Senate shall consist of thirty-one members.

article3.question: How many members does the Texas House of Representatives consist of?
article3.reference: The House of Representatives shall consist of 150 members.

article3.question: What is the term of office for Texas Senators?
article3.reference: Sec. 3. ELECTION AND TERM OF OFFICE OF SENATORS. The Senators shall be chosen by the qualified voters for the term of four years...

article3.question: To ensure that half of the Senate is chosen biennially, how are Senators divided after each apportionment?
article3.reference: ...the Senators elected after each apportionment shall be divided by lot into two classes. The seats of the Senators of the first class shall be vacated at the expiration of the first two years, and those of the second class at the expiration of four years, so that one half of the Senators shall be chosen biennially thereafter.

article3.question: What is the term of office for members of the House of Representatives?
article3.reference: Sec. 4. ELECTION AND TERM OF MEMBERS OF HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. The Members of the House of Representatives shall be chosen by the qualified voters for the term of two years.

article3.question: How often shall the Legislature meet?
options: Only when convened by the Governor.
article3.reference: Sec. 5. MEETINGS; ORDER OF BUSINESS. (a) The Legislature shall meet every two years at such time as may be provided by law and at other times when convened by the Governor.

article3.question: What is the minimum age qualification for a Texas Senator?
article3.reference: Sec. 6. QUALIFICATIONS OF SENATORS. No person shall be a Senator, unless he... shall have attained the age of twenty-six years.

article3.question: To be a Senator, a person must have been a resident of Texas for how long immediately preceding the election?
article3.reference: Sec. 6. QUALIFICATIONS OF SENATORS. No person shall be a Senator, unless he... shall have been a resident of this State five years next preceding his election...

article3.question: What is the minimum age qualification for a member of the House of Representatives?
article3.reference: Sec. 7. QUALIFICATIONS OF REPRESENTATIVES. No person shall be a Representative, unless he... shall have attained the age of twenty-one years.

article3.question: To be a Representative, a person must have been a resident of their district for how long?
article3.reference: Sec. 7. QUALIFICATIONS OF REPRESENTATIVES. No person shall be a Representative, unless he... shall have been a resident of this State two years next preceding his election, the last year thereof a resident of the district for which he shall be chosen...

article3.question: According to Section 8, who is the judge of the qualifications and election of the members of each House?
article3.answer: Each House shall be the judge of its own members.
options: Each House shall be the judge of its own members.
article3.reference: Sec. 8. EACH HOUSE JUDGE OF QUALIFICATIONS AND ELECTION OF ITS MEMBERS; ELECTION CONTESTS. Each House shall be the judge of the qualifications and election of its own members...

article3.question: If the office of Lieutenant Governor becomes vacant, what body convenes to elect a replacement?
article3.answer: The Committee of the Whole Senate.
options: The Committee of the Whole Senate.
A special statewide election is held.
article3.reference: Sec. 9. PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE OF SENATE... If the office of Lieutenant Governor becomes vacant, the President pro tempore of the Senate shall convene the Committee of the Whole Senate within 30 days after the vacancy occurs.

article3.question: What constitutes a quorum to do business in each House?
article3.reference: Sec. 10. QUORUM; ADJOURNMENTS FROM DAY TO DAY; COMPELLING ATTENDANCE. Two-thirds of each House shall constitute a quorum to do business...

article3.question: With the consent of what fraction of its members can a House expel a member?
article3.reference: Sec. 11. RULES OF PROCEDURE; PUNISHMENT OR EXPULSION OF MEMBER. Each House may... with the consent of two-thirds, expel a member, but not a second time for the same offencet.

article3.question: A vote taken by either house must be a record vote with each member's vote entered in the journal for what matter?
article3.answer: A resolution proposing a constitutional amendment.
options: A resolution of a purely ceremonial or honorary nature.
A resolution proposing a constitutional amendment.
A vote to adjourn for the day.
article3.reference: Sec. 12. JOURNALS OF PROCEEDINGS; RECORD VOTES. (b) A vote taken by either house must be by record vote with the vote of each member entered in the journal of that house if the vote is on final passage of a bill, a resolution proposing or ratifying a constitutional amendment...

article3.question: If the Governor fails to issue a writ of election to fill a vacancy within 20 days, who is then authorized to order the election?
article3.answer: The returning officer of the district.
options: The presiding officer of that House.
The returning officer of the district.
article3.reference: Sec. 13. VACANCY IN LEGISLATURE. (a) ...should the Governor fail to issue a writ of election to fill any such vacancy within twenty days after it occurs, the returning officer of the district in which such vacancy may have happened, shall be authorized to order an election for that purpose.

article3.question: Senators and Representatives are privileged from arrest during the legislative session, except in what cases?
article3.answer: Treason, felony, or breach of the peace.
options: Treason, felony, or breach of the peace.
article3.reference: Sec. 14. PRIVILEGE FROM ARREST DURING LEGISLATIVE SESSION. Senators and Representatives shall, except in cases of treason, felony, or breach of the peace, be privileged from arrest during the session of the Legislature...

article3.question: Each House may punish a non-member for disrespectful or disorderly conduct by imprisonment for a period not to exceed what?
article3.reference: Sec. 15. DISRESPECTFUL OR DISORDERLY CONDUCT; OBSTRUCTION OF PROCEEDINGS. Each House may punish, by imprisonment... provided, such imprisonment shall not, at any one time, exceed forty-eight hours.

article3.question: The sessions of each House shall be open, with what exception?
article3.answer: The Senate when in Executive session.
options: The Senate when in Executive session.
article3.reference: Sec. 16. OPEN SESSIONS. The sessions of each House shall be open, except the Senate when in Executive session.

article3.question: Neither House can adjourn for more than how many days without the consent of the other?
article3.reference: Sec. 17. ADJOURNMENTS. Neither House shall, without the consent of the other, adjourn for more than three days...

article3.question: A Senator or Representative is ineligible to be appointed to what kind of office during their term?
article3.answer: Any civil office of profit under this State which shall have been created during such term.
options: Any civil office of profit under this State which shall have been created during such term.
article3.reference: Sec. 18. INELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER OFFICES... No Senator or Representative shall, during the term for which he was elected, be eligible to (1) any civil office of profit under this State which shall have been created, or the emoluments of which may have been increased, during such term...

article3.question: Which of these officials is ineligible to be a member of the Legislature during their term?
article3.reference: Sec. 19. INELIGIBILITY OF PERSONS HOLDING OTHER OFFICES. No judge of any Court, Secretary of State, Attorney General, Clerk of any Court of Record, or any person holding a lucrative office under the United States, or this State, or any foreign government shall during the term for which he is elected or appointed, be eligible to the Legislature.

article3.question: Who is ineligible to serve in the Legislature until they have obtained a discharge for all public moneys entrusted to them?
article3.answer: A person who has been a collector of taxes.
options: A person who has been a collector of taxes.
A person who has declared bankruptcy.
A person who has served on a grand jury.
article3.reference: Sec. 20. ELIGIBILITY OF COLLECTORS OF TAXES OR PERSONS ENTRUSTED WITH PUBLIC MONEY. No person who at any time may have been a collector of taxes, or who may have been otherwise entrusted with public money, shall be eligible to the Legislature... until he shall have obtained a discharge for the amount of such collections...

article3.question: What protection is given to a member of the Legislature for words spoken in debate?
article3.answer: No member shall be questioned in any other place for words spoken in debate in either House.
options: They have absolute immunity from slander laws.
They can be sued civilly but not charged criminally.
They are protected only if the words are true.
No member shall be questioned in any other place for words spoken in debate in either House.
article3.reference: Sec. 21. WORDS SPOKEN IN DEBATE. No member shall be questioned in any other place for words spoken in debate in either House.

article3.question: What must a member of the Legislature do if they have a personal or private interest in a pending bill?
article3.answer: Disclose the fact to the House and not vote thereon.
options: Vote in favor of the bill to represent their constituents.
Abstain from debate but still vote.
Disclose the fact to the House and not vote thereon.
Recuse themselves from the entire session.
article3.reference: Sec. 22. DISCLOSURE OF PERSONAL OR PRIVATE INTEREST IN MEASURE OR BILL; NOT TO VOTE. A member who has a personal or private interest in any measure or bill... shall disclose the fact to the House, of which he is a member, and shall not vote thereon.

article3.question: What happens if a Senator or Representative removes their residence from the district for which they were elected?
article3.answer: Their office shall thereby become vacant.
options: They must win a special election to retain their seat.
Their office shall thereby become vacant.
They can continue to serve until the end of their term.
They are censured by their respective House.
article3.reference: Sec. 23. VACANCY FOLLOWING REMOVAL FROM DISTRICT OR COUNTY FROM WHICH ELECTED. If any Senator or Representative remove his residence from the district or county for which he was elected, his office shall thereby become vacant...

article3.question: What is the maximum duration of a Regular Session of the Legislature?
article3.reference: Sec. 24. COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES OF MEMBERS OF LEGISLATURE; DURATION OF REGULAR SESSIONS. ... (b) No Regular Session shall be of longer duration than one hundred and forty (140) days.

article3.question: Who sets the salary and per diem for members of the Legislature?
article3.answer: The Texas Ethics Commission, with voter approval for salary changes.
options: The Texas Ethics Commission, with voter approval for salary changes.
article3.reference: Sec. 24a. TEXAS ETHICS COMMISSION; LEGISLATIVE SALARIES AND PER DIEM. (a) The Texas Ethics Commission is a state agency... (e) The commission may recommend the salary of the members of the legislature... (f) At each general election... the voters shall approve or disapprove the salary recommended by the commission...

article3.question: The Legislative Redistricting Board is created if the Legislature fails to do what?
article3.answer: Apportion the state into senatorial and representative districts after the census.
options: Apportion the state into senatorial and representative districts after the census.
article3.reference: Sec. 28. TIME FOR APPORTIONMENT; APPORTIONMENT BY LEGISLATIVE REDISTRICTING BOARD. The Legislature shall, at its first regular session after the publication of each United States decennial census, apportion the state into senatorial and representative districts... In the event the Legislature... fail to make such apportionment, same shall be done by the Legislative Redistricting Board of Texas...

article3.question: Who are the five members of the Legislative Redistricting Board?
article3.answer: The Lieutenant Governor, Speaker of the House, Attorney General, Comptroller, and Commissioner of the General Land Office.
options: The Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Speaker of the House, Attorney General, and Secretary of State.
The Lieutenant Governor, Speaker of the House, Attorney General, Comptroller, and Commissioner of the General Land Office.
Five members of the Senate appointed by the Lieutenant Governor.
Five members of the House appointed by the Speaker.
article3.reference: ...the Legislative Redistricting Board of Texas, which is hereby created, and shall be composed of five (5) members, as follows: The Lieutenant Governor, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, the Attorney General, the Comptroller of Public Accounts and the Commissioner of the General Land Office...

article3.question: What is the official enacting clause of all laws in Texas?
article3.answer: Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas.
options: The people of Texas hereby declare...
It is ordered by the State of Texas...
By the authority vested in this Legislature...
Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas.
article3.reference: Sec. 29. ENACTING CLAUSE OF LAWS. The enacting clause of all laws shall be: 'Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Texas.'

article3.question: Can a bill be amended during its passage through either House so as to change its original purpose?
options: Yes, if the amendment is approved by the Governor.
Only if it is a revenue bill.
article3.reference: Sec. 30. LAWS PASSED BY BILL; AMENDMENTS CHANGING PURPOSE PROHIBITED. No law shall be passed, except by bill, and no bill shall be so amended in its passage through either House, as to change its original purpose.

article3.question: What is required for a bill to have the force of a law?
article3.answer: It must have been read on three several days in each House.
options: It must be sponsored by at least ten members.
It must have a public hearing in each county.
It must have been read on three several days in each House.
It must be approved by the Attorney General.
article3.reference: Sec. 32. READING ON THREE SEVERAL DAYS. No bill shall have the force of a law, until it has been read on three several days in each House...

article3.question: Where must all bills for raising revenue originate?
article3.reference: Sec. 33. ORIGINATION OF REVENUE BILLS IN HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. All bills for raising revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives.

article3.question: Except for general appropriation bills, a bill shall not contain more than how many subjects?
article3.reference: Sec. 35. SUBJECTS AND TITLES OF BILLS. (a) No bill, (except general appropriation bills...) shall contain more than one subject.

article3.question: How long after the adjournment of a legislative session does a new law typically take effect?
article3.reference: Sec. 39. TIME OF TAKING EFFECT OF LAWS. No law passed by the Legislature, except the general appropriation act, shall take effect or go into force until ninety days after the adjournment of the session...

article3.question: When the Legislature is convened in a special session, what is the duration limited to?
article3.reference: Sec. 40. SPECIAL SESSIONS; SUBJECTS OF LEGISLATION; DURATION. ...and no such session shall be of longer duration than thirty days.

article3.question: How are votes given in all elections by the Senate and House of Representatives, except for their own officers?
article3.reference: Sec. 41. ELECTIONS BY SENATE AND HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. In all elections by the Senate and House of Representatives, jointly or separately, the vote shall be given viva voce, except in the election of their officers.

article3.question: The Legislature may authorize charitable bingo games conducted by which of the following organizations?
article3.answer: A church, synagogue, or volunteer fire department.
options: A church, synagogue, or volunteer fire department.
article3.reference: Sec. 47. ... (b) The Legislature by law may authorize and regulate bingo games conducted by a church, synagogue, religious society, volunteer fire department, nonprofit veterans organization, fraternal organization, or nonprofit organization supporting medical research or treatment programs.

article3.question: What is the maximum debt the State can create to supply 'casual deficiencies of revenue'?
article3.reference: Sec. 49. STATE DEBTS. (a) No debt shall be created by or on behalf of the State, except: (1) to supply casual deficiencies of revenue, not to exceed in the aggregate at any one time two hundred thousand dollars;

article3.question: Except in an emergency, the Legislature cannot pass an appropriation bill that exceeds what?
article3.answer: The cash and anticipated revenue of the funds from which the appropriation is made.
options: The cash and anticipated revenue of the funds from which the appropriation is made.
article3.reference: Sec. 49a. ... (b) Except in the case of emergency and imperative public necessity... no appropriation in excess of the cash and anticipated revenue of the funds from which such appropriation is to be made shall be valid.

article3.question: The Veterans' Land Board is composed of the Commissioner of the General Land Office and how many citizens?
article3.reference: Sec. 49-b. VETERANS' LAND BOARD... (a) The Veterans' Land Board shall be composed of the Commissioner of the General Land Office and two (2) citizens of the State of Texas...

article3.question: According to Section 51, the Legislature has no power to grant public money to any individual, with what exception?
article3.reference: Sec. 51. GRANTS OF PUBLIC MONEY PROHIBITED. The Legislature shall have no power to make any grant... of public moneys to any individual... provided that the provisions of this Section shall not be construed so as to prevent the grant of aid in cases of public calamity.

article3.question: What does Section 56 of Article 3 generally prohibit?
article3.answer: The passage of local or special laws.
options: The passage of local or special laws.
article3.reference: Sec. 56. PROHIBITED LOCAL AND SPECIAL LAWS. (a) The Legislature shall not, except as otherwise provided in this Constitution, pass any local or special law...

article3.question: Before a local or special law can be passed, what must happen?
article3.answer: Notice of the intention to apply for the law must be published in the locality at least 30 days prior.
options: It must be approved by the local city council.
A statewide referendum must be held.
It must be signed by the Governor first.
Notice of the intention to apply for the law must be published in the locality at least 30 days prior.
article3.reference: Sec. 57. NOTICE OF INTENTION TO APPLY FOR LOCAL OR SPECIAL LAW. No local or special law shall be passed, unless notice of the intention to apply therefor shall have been published in the locality... at least thirty days prior to the introduction into the Legislature of such bill...

article3.question: Where shall the Legislature hold its sessions, according to Section 58?
options: In any city with a population over 1 million.
In a location that rotates between major cities.
article3.reference: Sec. 58. SEAT OF GOVERNMENT. The Legislature shall hold its sessions at the City of Austin, which is hereby declared to be the seat of government.

article4.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a member of the Executive Department of the State of Texas in Article 4, Section 1?
article4.answer: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
options: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
article4.reference: Sec. 1. OFFICERS CONSTITUTING EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT. The Executive Department of the State shall consist of a Governor, who shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the State, a Lieutenant Governor, Secretary of State, Comptroller of Public Accounts, Commissioner of the General Land Office, and Attorney General.

article4.question: According to Article 4, Section 2, which officer of the Executive Department is NOT elected by the qualified voters of the State?
article4.answer: Secretary of State
article4.reference: Sec. 2. ELECTION OF OFFICERS OF EXECUTIVE DEPARTMENT. All the above officers of the Executive Department (except Secretary of State) shall be elected by the qualified voters of the State...

article4.question: In the case of a tie vote for an Executive Office, how is the winner chosen?
article4.answer: By a joint vote of both Houses of the Legislature.
options: By a joint vote of both Houses of the Legislature.
The Secretary of State casts the deciding vote.
article4.reference: But, if two or more persons shall have the highest and an equal number of votes for either of said offices, one of them shall be immediately chosen to such office by joint vote of both Houses of the Legislature.

article4.question: If a person who received the highest number of votes for Governor dies or fails to qualify, who becomes Governor?
article4.answer: The person having the highest number of votes for Lieutenant Governor.
options: The previous Governor remains in office.
The person having the highest number of votes for Lieutenant Governor.
article4.reference: Sec. 3a. ...If, at the time the Legislature shall canvass the election returns for the offices of Governor and Lieutenant Governor, the person receiving the highest number of votes for the office of Governor... has died, fails to qualify, or for any other reason is unable to assume the office of Governor, then the person having the highest number of votes for the office of Lieutenant Governor shall become Governor...

article4.question: What is the term of office for the Governor of Texas?
article4.answer: Four years.
article4.reference: Sec. 4. INSTALLATION OF GOVERNOR; TERM; ELIGIBILITY. The Governor elected at the general election in 1974, and thereafter... shall hold his office for the term of four years...

article4.question: What is the minimum age requirement to be eligible for the office of Governor?
article4.answer: Thirty years of age.
article4.reference: He shall be at least thirty years of age, a citizen of the United States, and shall have resided in this State at least five years immediately preceding his election.

article4.question: According to Article 4, Section 6, which of the following is the Governor prohibited from doing while in office?
article4.answer: Holding any other office: civil, military or corporate.
options: Receiving a pension from previous government service.
Holding any other office: civil, military or corporate.
Serving on the board of a non-profit organization.
article4.reference: Sec. 6. HOLDING OTHER OFFICE... During the time he holds the office of Governor, he shall not hold any other office: civil, military or corporate; nor shall he practice any profession, and receive compensation...

article4.question: The Governor has the power to call forth the militia for what purpose?
article4.answer: To execute the laws of the State, to suppress insurrections, and to repel invasions.
options: To assist in local law enforcement operations.
To provide security for state buildings.
To execute the laws of the State, to suppress insurrections, and to repel invasions.
To serve as a personal guard for the Governor.
article4.reference: Sec. 7. GOVERNOR AS COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF OF MILITARY FORCES. He shall have power to call forth the militia to execute the laws of the State, to suppress insurrections, and to repel invasions.

article4.question: Under what circumstance may the Governor convene the Legislature at a place other than the seat of Government?
article4.answer: If the seat of Government is in possession of the public enemy or in case of the prevalence of disease threat.
options: For the convenience of the legislators.
If there is a major infrastructure failure in Austin.
If the Governor believes a different location would be more productive.
If the seat of Government is in possession of the public enemy or in case of the prevalence of disease threat.
article4.reference: Sec. 8. CONVENING LEGISLATURE ON EXTRAORDINARY OCCASIONS. (a) The Governor may, on extraordinary occasions, convene the Legislature at the seat of Government, or at a different place, in case that should be in possession of the public enemy or in case of the prevalence of disease threat.

article4.question: What is the Governor's primary duty regarding the laws of the state, as stated in Section 10?
article4.answer: He shall cause the laws to be faithfully executed.
options: He shall have the power to interpret the laws.
He shall cause the laws to be faithfully executed.
He can suspend laws he disagrees with.
He is responsible for writing new laws.
article4.reference: Sec. 10. EXECUTION OF LAWS AND CONDUCT OF BUSINESS... He shall cause the laws to be faithfully executed...

article4.question: In criminal cases, except for treason and impeachment, the Governor has the power to grant pardons based on what?
article4.answer: The written signed recommendation and advice of the Board of Pardons and Paroles.
options: A majority vote of the Legislature.
The recommendation of the Attorney General.
The written signed recommendation and advice of the Board of Pardons and Paroles.
article4.reference: Sec. 11. ... (b) In all criminal cases, except treason and impeachment, the Governor shall have power... on the written signed recommendation and advice of the Board of Pardons and Paroles, or a majority thereof, to grant reprieves and commutations of punishment and pardons...

article4.question: How long is the single reprieve that the Governor has the power to grant in any capital case?
article4.answer: Not to exceed thirty (30) days.
article4.reference: The Governor shall have the power to grant one reprieve in any capital case for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days...

article4.question: According to Section 11A, which branch of government has the power to suspend the imposition of a sentence and place a defendant on probation?
article4.answer: The Courts of the State of Texas.
options: The Board of Pardons and Paroles.
The Courts of the State of Texas.
article4.reference: Sec. 11A. SUSPENSION OF SENTENCE; PROBATION. The Courts of the State of Texas having original jurisdiction of criminal actions shall have the power, after conviction, to suspend the imposition or execution of sentence and to place the defendant upon probation...

article4.question: How are vacancies in State or district offices filled, unless otherwise provided by law?
article4.answer: By appointment of the Governor.
article4.reference: Sec. 12. VACANCIES IN STATE OR DISTRICT OFFICES. (a) All vacancies in State or district offices, except members of the Legislature, shall be filled unless otherwise provided by law by appointment of the Governor.

article4.question: If the Governor vetoes a bill, what vote is required by both Houses of the Legislature to override the veto and make it law?
article4.answer: A vote of two-thirds of the members present.
options: A simple majority of the members present.
A vote of three-fifths of the members present.
A vote of two-thirds of the members present.
article4.reference: If after such reconsideration, two-thirds of the members present agree to pass the bill, it shall be sent... to the other House... and, if approved by two-thirds of the members of that House, it shall become a law...

article4.question: What happens if a bill is not returned by the Governor with his objections within ten days (Sundays excepted)?
article4.answer: It shall be a law, in like manner as if he had signed it.
options: The Legislature must vote on it again.
It shall be a law, in like manner as if he had signed it.
It must be resubmitted in the next session.
article4.reference: If any bill shall not be returned by the Governor with his objections within ten days (Sundays excepted) after it shall have been presented to him, the same shall be a law, in like manner as if he had signed it...

article4.question: What special power does the Governor have regarding bills containing several items of appropriation?
article4.answer: He may object to one or more of such items, and approve the other portion of the bill.
options: He must approve or veto the entire bill.
He can reduce the amount of any appropriation item.
He may object to one or more of such items, and approve the other portion of the bill.
He can add new appropriation items to the bill.
article4.reference: If any bill presented to the Governor contains several items of appropriation he may object to one or more of such items, and approve the other portion of the bill.

article4.question: By virtue of his office, the Lieutenant Governor holds what position?
article4.answer: President of the Senate.
article4.reference: Sec. 16. LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR. ... (b) The Lieutenant Governor shall by virtue of his office be President of the Senate...

article4.question: When does the Lieutenant Governor have the power to cast a vote in the Senate?
article4.answer: When the Senate is equally divided.
options: When the Senate is equally divided.
article4.reference: ...and shall have, when in Committee of the Whole, a right to debate and vote on all questions; and when the Senate is equally divided to give the casting vote.

article4.question: What does the Seal of the State of Texas consist of?
article4.answer: A Star of five points encircled by olive and live oak branches.
options: A lone star with the words 'Don't Tread on Me'.
An image of the Alamo with six flags.
A Star of five points encircled by olive and live oak branches.
An eagle perched on a cactus.
article4.reference: Sec. 19. SEAL OF STATE. ... The Seal of the State shall be a Star of five points encircled by olive and live oak branches, and the words 'The State of Texas.'

article4.question: How does the Secretary of State assume office?
article4.answer: Appointed by the Governor, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
options: Elected by the qualified voters of the State.
Appointed by the Governor, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The position is held by the Lieutenant Governor ex officio.
article4.reference: Sec. 21. SECRETARY OF STATE. There shall be a Secretary of State, who shall be appointed by the Governor, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate...

article4.question: What is a primary duty of the Attorney General?
article4.answer: To represent the State in all suits and pleas in the Supreme Court of the State.
options: To oversee all local law enforcement agencies.
To prosecute all felony cases in the state.
To serve as the state's chief election officer.
To represent the State in all suits and pleas in the Supreme Court of the State.
article4.reference: Sec. 22. ATTORNEY GENERAL. The Attorney General shall represent the State in all suits and pleas in the Supreme Court of the State in which the State may be a party...

article4.question: What is the term of office for elected state officers like the Comptroller and Attorney General?
article4.answer: Four years.
article4.reference: Sec. 23. TERM AND SALARY OF ELECTED STATE OFFICERS... The Comptroller of Public Accounts, the Commissioner of the General Land Office, the Attorney General, and any statutory State officer who is elected by the electorate of Texas at large... shall each hold office for the term of four years.

article4.question: What must officers of the Executive Department and managers of State institutions do semi-annually?
article4.answer: Make a report under oath to the Governor of all moneys received and disbursed.
options: Publish their budget in a newspaper.
Submit to a financial audit by the Comptroller.
Make a report under oath to the Governor of all moneys received and disbursed.
article4.reference: Sec. 24. ACCOUNTS AND REPORTS OF EXECUTIVE OFFICERS TO GOVERNOR... An account shall be kept by the officers of the Executive Department, and by all officers and managers of State institutions, of all moneys... and a semi-annual report thereof shall be made to the Governor under oath.

article4.question: An officer or manager who wilfully makes a false report to the Governor is guilty of what?
article4.answer: Perjury.
article4.reference: ...and any officer or manager who, at any time, shall wilfully make a false report or give false information, shall be guilty of perjury, and so adjudged, and punished accordingly, and removed from office.

article4.question: What is the term of office for a Notary Public in Texas?
article4.answer: Not less than two years nor more than four years.
options: Not less than two years nor more than four years.
article4.reference: Sec. 26. NOTARIES PUBLIC. ... (b) The terms of office of Notaries Public shall be not less than two years nor more than four years as provided by law.

article5.question: According to Article 5, Section 1, the judicial power of the State of Texas is vested in which of the following courts?
article5.answer: One Supreme Court, one Court of Criminal Appeals, Courts of Appeals, and District Courts, among others.
options: Only a Supreme Court and District Courts.
One Supreme Court, one Court of Criminal Appeals, Courts of Appeals, and District Courts, among others.
Federal Courts, State Courts, and Municipal Courts.
article5.reference: Sec. 1. JUDICIAL POWER VESTED IN COURTS; LEGISLATIVE POWER REGARDING COURTS. The judicial power of this State shall be vested in one Supreme Court, in one Court of Criminal Appeals, in Courts of Appeals, in District Courts, in County Courts, in Commissioners Courts, in Courts of Justices of the Peace, and in such other courts as may be provided by law.

article5.question: Under what circumstance does the office of a Justice or Judge of an Appellate or District Court become vacant due to age?
article5.answer: On the expiration of the term during which the incumbent reaches the age of seventy-five (75) years.
options: At the end of the calendar year in which they turn 75.
On the expiration of the term during which the incumbent reaches the age of seventy-five (75) years.
They may serve for life, regardless of age.
article5.reference: Sec. 1-a. ... The office of every such Justice and Judge shall become vacant on the expiration of the term during which the incumbent reaches the age of seventy-five (75) years or such earlier age, not less than seventy (70) years, as the Legislature may prescribe...

article5.question: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct is composed of how many members?
article5.reference: Sec. 1-a. ...(2) The State Commission on Judicial Conduct consists of thirteen (13) members, to wit:...

article5.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid reason for the State Commission on Judicial Conduct to recommend removal of a judge from office?
options: Wilful or persistent violation of rules promulgated by the Supreme Court of Texas.
Incompetence in performing the duties of the office.
Willful violation of the Code of Judicial Conduct.
article5.reference: Sec. 1-a. ...(6)A. Any Justice or Judge... may... be removed from office for willful or persistent violation of rules promulgated by the Supreme Court of Texas, incompetence in performing the duties of the office, willful violation of the Code of Judicial Conduct, or willful or persistent conduct that is clearly inconsistent with the proper performance of his duties...

article5.question: How many Justices make up the Supreme Court of Texas?
article5.answer: A Chief Justice and eight Justices.
options: A Chief Justice and six Justices.
A Chief Justice and eight Justices.
A number determined by the Legislature each session.
article5.reference: Sec. 2. SUPREME COURT; JUSTICES. (a) The Supreme Court shall consist of the Chief Justice and eight Justices...

article5.question: What is the minimum age requirement to be eligible to serve as a Justice of the Supreme Court?
article5.reference: Sec. 2. ...(b) No person shall be eligible to serve in the office of Chief Justice or Justice of the Supreme Court unless the person: ... (3) has attained the age of thirty-five years;

article5.question: To be eligible for the Supreme Court, a person must have been a practicing lawyer or judge for a combined total of at least how many years?
article5.reference: Sec. 2. ...(b)(4) has been either: (A) a practicing lawyer licensed in the State of Texas for at least ten years; or (B) a practicing lawyer licensed in the State of Texas and judge of a state court or county court... for a combined total of at least ten years;

article5.question: What is the appellate jurisdiction of the Supreme Court?
article5.answer: It extends to all cases except in criminal law matters.
options: It is limited to cases involving the constitutionality of a statute.
It extends to all cases except in criminal law matters.
It only hears appeals from District Courts.
article5.reference: Sec. 3. JURISDICTION OF SUPREME COURT. (a) ...Its appellate jurisdiction shall be final and shall extend to all cases except in criminal law matters...

article5.question: The Supreme Court has the power to issue which writ, which is necessary for a person to be brought before a court?
article5.reference: The Supreme Court and the Justices thereof shall have power to issue writs of habeas corpus, as may be prescribed by law...

article5.question: What power does the Legislature have regarding direct appeals to the Supreme Court?
article5.answer: To provide by law for a direct appeal from a trial court order granting or denying an injunction based on the constitutionality of a statute.
options: The Legislature cannot regulate appeals to the Supreme Court.
To require all felony cases to be appealed directly to the Supreme Court.
To provide by law for a direct appeal from a trial court order granting or denying an injunction based on the constitutionality of a statute.
To prohibit all direct appeals to the Supreme Court.
article5.reference: Sec. 3-b. DIRECT APPEAL FROM ORDER GRANTING OR DENYING INJUNCTION. The Legislature shall have the power to provide by law, for an appeal direct to the Supreme Court of this State from an order of any trial court granting or denying an interlocutory or permanent injunction on the grounds of the constitutionality or unconstitutionality of any statute of this State...

article5.question: How many Judges make up the Court of Criminal Appeals?
article5.answer: Eight Judges and one Presiding Judge.
options: Six Judges and one Presiding Judge.
Eight Judges and one Presiding Judge.
article5.reference: Sec. 4. COURT OF CRIMINAL APPEALS; JUDGES. (a) The Court of Criminal Appeals shall consist of eight Judges and one Presiding Judge.

article5.question: When the Court of Criminal Appeals sits 'en banc' to hear a case, how many Judges constitute a quorum?
article5.reference: When convened en banc, five Judges shall constitute a quorum and the concurrence of five Judges shall be necessary for a decision.

article5.question: According to Article 5, Section 5, the appeal of all cases in which the death penalty has been assessed shall be to which court?
article5.reference: Sec. 5. JURISDICTION OF COURT OF CRIMINAL APPEALS. ... (b) The appeal of all cases in which the death penalty has been assessed shall be to the Court of Criminal Appeals.

article5.question: What is 'discretionary review' by the Court of Criminal Appeals?
article5.answer: A review of a Court of Appeals decision that is not a matter of right, but of sound judicial discretion.
options: A mandatory review of all felony convictions.
A review that can be requested by any citizen.
A review of a Court of Appeals decision that is not a matter of right, but of sound judicial discretion.
A review conducted by the Governor.
article5.reference: In addition, the Court of Criminal Appeals may, on its own motion, review a decision of a Court of Appeals in a criminal case... Discretionary review by the Court of Criminal Appeals is not a matter of right, but of sound judicial discretion.

article5.question: What is the term of office for a Clerk of an Appellate Court?
article5.reference: Sec. 5a. CLERKS OF APPELLATE COURTS. ...may hold office for four years subject to removal by the appointing court for good cause...

article5.question: Justices of the Courts of Appeals must have the same qualifications as whom?
article5.reference: Sec. 6. COURTS OF APPEALS; JUSTICES; JURISDICTION. (a) ... The Justices shall have the qualifications prescribed for Justices of the Supreme Court.

article5.question: To be eligible for election as a district judge, a person must have been a practicing lawyer or judge for how many years preceding the election?
article5.reference: Sec. 7. ... (b) To be eligible for appointment or election as a district judge, a person must: ... (3) have been a practicing lawyer or a Judge of a Court in this State, or both combined, for eight years next preceding the judge's election...

article5.question: What is the term of office for a district judge?
article5.reference: Sec. 7. ... (c) A district judge shall hold the office for the term of four years...

article5.question: If the Judicial Districts Board fails to make a statewide apportionment after a census, what body is then required to do so?
article5.reference: Sec. 7a. ... If the Judicial Districts Board fails to make a statewide apportionment by that date, the Legislative Redistricting Board established by Article III, Section 28, of this constitution shall make a statewide reapportionment of the judicial districts...

article5.question: What kind of jurisdiction does a District Court have over the County Commissioners Court?
article5.answer: Appellate jurisdiction and general supervisory control.
options: Appellate jurisdiction and general supervisory control.
article5.reference: Sec. 8. JURISDICTION OF DISTRICT COURTS. ... The District Court shall have appellate jurisdiction and general supervisory control over the County Commissioners Court...

article5.question: When is a judge disqualified from sitting in a case?
article5.answer: When the judge may be interested in the case, or is related to one of the parties.
options: If the judge has previously ruled against one of the attorneys.
If the judge resides in the same county as one of the parties.
When the judge may be interested in the case, or is related to one of the parties.
If the judge has publicly expressed an opinion on a similar legal issue.
article5.reference: Sec. 11. DISQUALIFICATION OF JUDGES... No judge shall sit in any case wherein the judge may be interested, or where either of the parties may be connected with the judge, either by affinity or consanguinity... or when the judge shall have been counsel in the case.

article5.question: What is an 'indictment' as defined in Article 5, Section 12?
article5.answer: A written instrument presented to a court by a grand jury charging a person with an offense.
options: A formal complaint filed by a citizen.
A written instrument presented to a court by an attorney for the State.
An arrest warrant signed by a magistrate.
A written instrument presented to a court by a grand jury charging a person with an offense.
article5.reference: Sec. 12. ... (b) An indictment is a written instrument presented to a court by a grand jury charging a person with the commission of an offense.

article5.question: In the District Courts, how many members compose a grand jury?
article5.reference: Sec. 13. GRAND AND PETIT JURIES IN DISTRICT COURTS: COMPOSITION AND VERDICT. Grand and petit juries in the District Courts shall be composed of twelve persons...

article5.question: How many members of a grand jury constitute a quorum to transact business and present bills?
article5.reference: ...but nine members of a grand jury shall be a quorum to transact business and present bills.

article5.question: What is the term of office for a County Judge?
options: It depends on the size of the county.
article5.reference: Sec. 15. COUNTY COURT; COUNTY JUDGE. ...there shall be elected in each county, by the qualified voters, a County Judge, who...shall hold his office for four years...

article5.question: A jury in the County Court shall consist of how many persons?
article5.reference: Sec. 17. COUNTY COURT: TERMS, PROSECUTIONS, AND JURIES. ... A jury in the County Court shall consist of six persons...

article5.question: In a county with a population of 50,000 or more, how shall it be divided for the convenience of the people?
article5.answer: Into not less than four and not more than eight precincts.
options: Into not less than two and not more than six precincts.
Into not less than four and not more than eight precincts.
article5.reference: Sec. 18. DIVISION OF COUNTIES INTO PRECINCTS... (a) Each county in the State with a population of 50,000 or more... shall be divided into not less than four and not more than eight precincts.

article5.question: Justice of the peace courts have exclusive jurisdiction in civil matters where the amount in controversy is what?
article5.reference: Sec. 19. JURISDICTION OF JUSTICE OF THE PEACE COURTS... exclusive jurisdiction in civil matters where the amount in controversy is two hundred dollars or less...

article5.question: Under what grounds may county officers like judges and constables be removed by the judges of the district courts?
article5.answer: For incompetency, official misconduct, or habitual drunkenness.
options: For disagreeing with a district court's ruling.
For incompetency, official misconduct, or habitual drunkenness.
For any reason deemed appropriate by the district judge.
article5.reference: Sec. 24. REMOVAL OF COUNTY OFFICERS. County judges, county attorneys, clerks of the district and county courts, justices of the peace, constables, and other county officers, may be removed by the judges of the district courts for incompetency, official misconduct, habitual drunkenness, or other causes defined by law...

article5.question: How is a vacancy in the office of County Judge or Justice of the Peace filled?
article5.answer: By the Commissioners Court until the next succeeding General Election.
options: By a special election held within 60 days.
The office remains vacant until the next election.
By the Commissioners Court until the next succeeding General Election.
article5.reference: Sec. 28. VACANCY IN JUDICIAL OFFICE. ... (b) A vacancy in the office of County Judge or Justice of the Peace shall be filled by the Commissioners Court until the next succeeding General Election.

article5.question: Who is responsible for the efficient administration of the judicial branch of the state?
options: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct.
article5.reference: Sec. 31. COURT ADMINISTRATION AND RULE-MAKING AUTHORITY. (a) The Supreme Court is responsible for the efficient administration of the judicial branch...

article6.question: According to Article 6, Section 1, which of the following classes of persons shall NOT be allowed to vote in Texas?
options: Persons who do not own property.
Persons who have recently moved to the state.
Persons who are not members of a political party.

article6.question: Besides being under 18, what is another reason a person may be disqualified from voting under Article 6, Section 1?
article6.answer: Persons who have been determined mentally incompetent by a court.
options: Persons who cannot read or write.
Persons who have been determined mentally incompetent by a court.
Persons who have served in the military of another country.
Persons who have previously failed to vote in an election.
article6.reference: Sec. 1. CLASSES OF PERSONS NOT ALLOWED TO VOTE. (a) The following classes of persons shall not be allowed to vote in this State: ... (2) persons who have been determined mentally incompetent by a court, subject to such exceptions as the Legislature may make;

article6.reference: Sec. 1. CLASSES OF PERSONS NOT ALLOWED TO VOTE. (a) The following classes of persons shall not be allowed to vote in this State: ... (3) persons convicted of any felony, subject to such exceptions as the Legislature may make.

article6.question: To be deemed a qualified voter in Texas, a person must be a citizen of the United States and what else?
article6.reference: Sec. 2. QUALIFIED VOTER; REGISTRATION; ABSENTEE VOTING. article6.question: According to Article 6, Section 2, what shall the requirement for voter registration NOT be considered?
article6.answer: A qualification of a voter (except for eligibility to vote).
options: A mandatory prerequisite for all elections.

article6.question: What does Article 6, Section 2(c) state shall be protected by laws regulating elections?
options: The privacy of the voting booth.
The accuracy of the vote count.
article6.reference: Sec. 2. ... (c) The privilege of free suffrage shall be protected by laws regulating elections and prohibiting under adequate penalties all undue influence in elections from power, bribery, tumult, or other improper practice.

article6.question: Under Section 2a, the Legislature may permit a person who meets all qualifications except local residency to vote for what offices?
article6.answer: Electors for President and Vice President, and all statewide offices.
options: Only for local city council and mayor.
Only for members of the Legislature.
Only for Governor and Lieutenant Governor.
Electors for President and Vice President, and all statewide offices.
article6.reference: Sec. 2a. ...permitting any person who is qualified to vote in this State except for the residence requirements... to vote for (1) electors for President and Vice President of the United States and (2) all offices, questions or propositions to be voted on by all voters throughout this State.

article6.question: A former resident of Texas who has moved to another state may be permitted to vote for President and Vice President by absentee ballot for a period not to exceed what?
article6.reference: Sec. 2a. ...permitting absentee voting for electors for President and Vice President of the United States in this State by former residents of this State... in no case for more than twenty-four (24) months.

article6.question: According to Article 6, Section 3, who has the right to vote for Mayor and all other elective officers in a city?
article6.answer: All qualified voters of the State who reside within the limits of that city.
options: Only property owners within the city.
All qualified voters of the State who reside within the limits of that city.
Anyone who works within the city limits.
Only residents who have lived in the city for more than one year.
article6.reference: Sec. 3. QUALIFICATIONS OF VOTERS IN MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS. All qualified voters of the State, as herein described, who reside within the limits of any city or corporate town, shall have the right to vote for Mayor and all other elective officers.

article6.question: In an election held for the purpose of issuing bonds or assuming debt, who is qualified to vote?
article6.answer: Only qualified voters of the State, county, or political sub-division where such election is held.
options: All registered voters in the State of Texas.
All property taxpayers in the district.

article6.reference: Sec. 4. ELECTIONS BY BALLOT; PURITY OF ELECTIONS; REGISTRATION OF VOTERS. In all elections by the people, the vote shall be by ballot...

article6.answer: The purity of the ballot box.

The historical record of the vote.
article6.reference: ...the Legislature shall provide for the numbering of tickets and make such other regulations as may be necessary to detect and punish fraud and preserve the purity of the ballot box...

article6.question: During their attendance at elections, voters are privileged from arrest except in what cases?
article6.answer: Treason, felony or breach of the peace.
options: Treason, felony or breach of the peace.
article6.reference: Sec. 5. VOTERS PRIVILEGED FROM ARREST. Voters shall, in all cases, except treason, felony or breach of the peace, be privileged from arrest during their attendance at elections, and in going to and returning therefrom.

article7.question: According to Article 7, Section 1, what is the duty of the Legislature regarding public schools?
article7.answer: To establish and make suitable provision for the support and maintenance of an efficient system of public free schools.
options: To set the curriculum for all public schools.
To directly manage the operation of all school districts.
To establish and make suitable provision for the support and maintenance of an efficient system of public free schools.
To ensure all students attend college.
article7.reference: Sec. 1. SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM OF PUBLIC FREE SCHOOLS. A general diffusion of knowledge being essential to the preservation of the liberties and rights of the people, it shall be the duty of the Legislature of the State to establish and make suitable provision for the support and maintenance of an efficient system of public free schools.

article7.question: What constitutes the Permanent School Fund, as defined in Article 7, Section 2?
article7.answer: All funds, lands, and other property set apart for public schools, including one half of the public domain of the State.
options: Only the funds generated from state property taxes.
Annual appropriations made by the Legislature.
All funds, lands, and other property set apart for public schools, including one half of the public domain of the State.
Donations from private corporations and individuals.
article7.reference: Sec. 2. PERMANENT SCHOOL FUND. All funds, lands and other property heretofore set apart and appropriated for the support of public schools; all the alternate sections of land reserved by the State... one half of the public domain of the State; and all sums of money that may come to the State from the sale of any portion of the same, shall constitute a permanent school fund.

article7.question: What portion of the revenue from State occupation taxes is set apart for the benefit of public free schools?
article7.reference: Sec. 3. TAXES FOR BENEFIT OF SCHOOLS... (a) One-fourth of the revenue derived from the State occupation taxes shall be set apart annually for the benefit of the public free schools.

article7.question: Who has the duty to set aside available funds to provide free text books for children in public schools?
article7.reference: Sec. 3. ... (b) It shall be the duty of the State Board of Education to set aside a sufficient amount of available funds to provide free text books for the use of children attending the public free schools of this State.

article7.question: If an independent school district's boundaries change, what happens to unissued bonds that were previously approved by voters?
article7.answer: They shall be abrogated, cancelled or invalidated.
options: They can be issued by the newly formed district.
They must be re-approved by voters in the new district.
They shall be abrogated, cancelled or invalidated.
Their value is transferred to the district's general fund.
article7.reference: Sec. 3-b. ...No tax for the maintenance of public free schools voted in any independent school district... nor any bonds voted in any such district, but unissued, shall be abrogated, cancelled or invalidated by change of any kind in the boundaries thereof.

article7.question: The Available School Fund consists of distributions from the permanent school fund, taxes, and what other source?
article7.answer: Appropriations made to the available school fund by the legislature.
options: Appropriations made to the available school fund by the legislature.
article7.reference: Sec. 5. ... The available school fund consists of the distributions made to it from the total return on all investment assets of the permanent school fund, the taxes authorized by this constitution or general law to be part of the available school fund, and appropriations made to the available school fund by the legislature.

article7.question: The total amount distributed from the permanent school fund to the available school fund in a year cannot exceed what percentage of the permanent school fund's average market value?
article7.reference: Sec. 5. ...(1) in each year of a state fiscal biennium must be an amount that is not more than six percent of the average of the market value of the permanent school fund...

article7.question: What is the policy regarding the use of the permanent or available school funds for sectarian schools?
article7.answer: They may not be appropriated to or used for the support of any sectarian school.
options: They can be used if the school also provides non-religious instruction.
They can be used with a two-thirds vote of the Legislature.
They may not be appropriated to or used for the support of any sectarian school.
They can be used to purchase textbooks for sectarian schools.
article7.reference: Sec. 5. ... (c) ... The permanent school fund and the available school fund may not be appropriated to or used for the support of any sectarian school.

article7.question: How is the available school fund distributed to the several counties?
options: Based on their property tax revenue.
article7.reference: The available school fund shall be distributed to the several counties according to their scholastic population and applied in the manner provided by law.

article7.question: Who holds the title to lands granted to the several counties for educational purposes?
article7.reference: Sec. 6. COUNTY SCHOOL LANDS AND PROCEEDS OF SALES HELD AS SCHOOL TRUST. All lands heretofore, or hereafter granted to the several counties of this State for educational purposes, are of right the property of said counties respectively, to which they were granted, and title thereto is vested in said counties...

article7.question: What is the maximum term length the Legislature can prescribe for members of the State Board of Education?
article7.reference: Sec. 8. STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION. The Legislature shall provide by law for a State Board of Education, whose members shall be appointed or elected... and shall serve for such terms as the Legislature shall prescribe not to exceed six years.

article7.question: According to Section 10, the Legislature shall establish a 'University of the first class' to be styled what?
article7.reference: Sec. 10. ESTABLISHMENT OF UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS... The Legislature shall as soon as practicable establish, organize and provide for the maintenance, support and direction of a University of the first class, to be located by a vote of the people of this State, and styled, 'The University of Texas'...

article7.question: What is the maximum percentage of the Permanent University Fund that can be invested in the securities of any one corporation?
article7.reference: Sec. 11a. INVESTMENT OF PERMANENT UNIVERSITY FUND. ...provided, however, that not more than one per cent (1%) of said fund shall be invested in the securities of any one (1) corporation...

article7.question: The Board of Regents may not own more than what percentage of the voting stock of any one corporation?
article7.reference: ...nor shall more than five per cent (5%) of the voting stock of any one (1) corporation be owned...

article7.question: Stocks are eligible for purchase by the Permanent University Fund only if the companies have paid dividends for how many consecutive years?
article7.reference: ...provided, further, that stocks eligible for purchase shall be restricted to stocks of companies incorporated within the United States which have paid dividends for five (5) consecutive years or longer immediately prior to the date of purchase...

article7.question: The Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas (Texas A&M) is constituted as a Branch of what institution?
options: It is a separate, independent system.
article7.reference: Sec. 13. AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGE. The Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas... is hereby made, and constituted a Branch of the University of Texas...

article7.question: Prairie View A&M University is established as an institution of the first class under the same governing board as what university?
options: The University of Texas at Austin.
article7.reference: Sec. 14. PRAIRIE VIEW A&M UNIVERSITY. Prairie View A&M University in Waller County is an institution of the first class under the direction of the same governing board as Texas A&M University...

article7.question: Which of the following universities is NOT listed under Section 17 as an eligible institution for funding from the special higher education fund?
article7.answer: The University of Texas at Austin.
options: The University of Texas at Austin.
article7.reference: Sec. 17. ... (b) The funds appropriated under Subsection (a) of this section shall be for the use of the following eligible agencies and institutions... (An institution that is entitled to participate in dedicated funding provided by Article VII, Section 18... may not be entitled to participate in the funding provided by this section.)

article7.question: How is the annual distribution from the Permanent University Fund to the Available University Fund split between the UT and A&M Systems?
article7.answer: One-third to the A&M System and two-thirds to the UT System.
options: It is split evenly between the two systems.
One-fourth to A&M and three-fourths to UT.
One-third to the A&M System and two-thirds to the UT System.
It is based on the student population of each system.
article7.reference: Sec. 18. ... (f) Out of one-third of the annual distribution from the permanent university fund to the available university fund, there shall be appropriated an annual sum... to the Board of Regents of The Texas A&M University System... Out of the other two-thirds of the annual distribution... there shall be appropriated an annual sum... to the Board of Regents of The University of Texas System...

article7.question: Which of the following is a component institution of The Texas A&M University System listed in Section 18?
options: The University of Texas at Arlington.
article7.reference: Sec. 18. ... at or for The Texas A&M University System administration and the following component institutions of the system: (1) Texas A&M University... (3) Tarleton State University;

article7.question: Which of the following is a component institution of The University of Texas System listed in Section 18?
article7.answer: The University of Texas at El Paso.
options: The University of Texas at El Paso.
article7.reference: Sec. 18. ... at or for The University of Texas System administration and the following component institutions of the system: ... (4) The University of Texas at El Paso;

article7.question: The proceeds from bonds issued under Section 18 for the UT and A&M systems may NOT be used for what purpose?
article7.answer: Student housing, intercollegiate athletics, or auxiliary enterprises.
options: Student housing, intercollegiate athletics, or auxiliary enterprises.
article7.reference: Sec. 18. ... (d) The proceeds of the bonds or notes issued under Subsection (a) or (b) of this section may not be used for the purpose of constructing, equipping, repairing, or rehabilitating buildings or other permanent improvements that are to be used for student housing, intercollegiate athletics, or auxiliary enterprises.

article7.question: What is the purpose of the Texas Tomorrow Fund, as described in Section 19?
article7.answer: To be a trust fund dedicated to the prepayment of tuition and fees for higher education.
options: To provide general funding for university research.
To fund construction of new university buildings.
To provide scholarships for low-income students.
To be a trust fund dedicated to the prepayment of tuition and fees for higher education.
article7.reference: Sec. 19. TEXAS TOMORROW FUND. (a) The Texas tomorrow fund is created as a trust fund dedicated to the prepayment of tuition and fees for higher education as provided by the general laws of this state for the prepaid higher education tuition program.

article7.question: What is the purpose of the Texas University Fund established in Section 20?
article7.answer: To provide a dedicated funding source for emerging research universities to achieve national prominence.
options: To fund all community colleges in the state.
To provide a dedicated funding source for emerging research universities to achieve national prominence.
To fund the Teacher Retirement System.
article7.reference: Sec. 20. TEXAS UNIVERSITY FUND. (a) There is established the Texas University Fund for the purpose of providing a dedicated, independent, and equitable source of funding to enable emerging research universities in this state to achieve national prominence as major research universities.

article7.question: A state university that is entitled to participate in the dedicated funding from the Permanent University Fund (under Sec. 18) is eligible to receive money from the Texas University Fund (Sec. 20). True or False?
options: Only if they are also designated as an emerging research university.
Only with a two-thirds vote of the legislature.
article7.reference: Sec. 20. ...(g) ...A state university that is entitled to participate in dedicated funding provided by Section 18 of this article is not eligible to receive money from the fund.

article8.question: According to Article 8, Section 1, all real and tangible personal property in the State shall be taxed in proportion to what?
article8.answer: Its value.
article8.reference: Sec. 1. ... (b) All real property and tangible personal property in this State... shall be taxed in proportion to its value, which shall be ascertained as may be provided by law.

article8.question: Which of the following groups shall never be required to pay an occupation tax?
article8.answer: Persons engaged in mechanical and agricultural pursuits.
options: Persons engaged in mechanical and agricultural pursuits.
Natural persons doing any business in the State.
