article8.reference: Sec. 1. ... (c) ... Persons engaged in mechanical and agricultural pursuits shall never be required to pay an occupation tax.

article8.question: The Legislature by general law may limit the maximum appraised value of a residence homestead for ad valorem tax purposes to the lesser of its most recent market value or what?
article8.answer: 110 percent, or a greater percentage, of the appraised value for the preceding tax year.
options: 105 percent of the appraised value for the preceding tax year.
110 percent, or a greater percentage, of the appraised value for the preceding tax year.
115 percent of the appraised value for the preceding tax year.
120 percent of the appraised value for the preceding tax year.
article8.reference: Sec. 1. ... (i) ...the Legislature by general law may limit the maximum appraised value of a residence homestead for ad valorem tax purposes in a tax year to the lesser of the most recent market value of the residence homestead... or 110 percent, or a greater percentage, of the appraised value of the residence homestead for the preceding tax year.

article8.question: The several counties of the State are authorized to levy ad valorem taxes for county road and flood control purposes not to exceed what rate?
article8.answer: Thirty cents (30) on each One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation.
options: Ten cents (10) on each One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation.
Twenty cents (20) on each One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation.
Thirty cents (30) on each One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation.
Fifty cents (50) on each One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation.
article8.reference: Sec. 1-a. COUNTY TAX LEVY FOR ROADS AND FLOOD CONTROL. The several counties of the State are authorized to levy ad valorem taxes... not to exceed thirty cents (30) on each One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation...

article8.question: What is the mandatory amount of the assessed taxable value of all residence homesteads that shall be exempt from all taxation for all State purposes?
article8.answer: Three Thousand Dollars ($3,000).
article8.reference: Sec. 1-b. RESIDENCE HOMESTEAD TAX EXEMPTIONS AND LIMITATIONS. (a) Three Thousand Dollars ($3,000) of the assessed taxable value of all residence homesteads... shall be exempt from all taxation for all State purposes.

article8.question: A surviving spouse of a member of the armed services killed in the line of duty is entitled to an exemption from ad valorem taxation on their residence homestead under what condition?
article8.answer: If the surviving spouse has not remarried since the death of the member.
options: Only if they have minor children.
If the surviving spouse has not remarried since the death of the member.
For a period of ten years after the member's death.
article8.reference: Sec. 1-b. ... (m) The legislature by general law may provide that the surviving spouse of a member of the armed services of the United States who is killed or fatally injured in the line of duty is entitled to an exemption... if the surviving spouse has not remarried since the death of the member of the armed services.

article8.question: What is the definition of 'agricultural use' for the purpose of tax assessment under Section 1-d?
article8.answer: The raising of livestock or growing of crops, fruit, flowers, and other products of the soil under natural conditions as a business venture for profit.
options: Any use of land outside of a city's limits.
The raising of livestock or growing of crops, fruit, flowers, and other products of the soil under natural conditions as a business venture for profit.
Operating a farmer's market or other retail agricultural business.
Holding land for future agricultural development.
article8.reference: Sec. 1-d. ASSESSMENT FOR TAX PURPOSES OF LANDS DESIGNATED FOR AGRICULTURAL USE. (a) ...'Agricultural use' means the raising of livestock or growing of crops, fruit, flowers, and other products of the soil under natural conditions as a business venture for profit, which business is the primary occupation and source of income of the owner.

article8.question: If land designated for agricultural use is subsequently diverted to another purpose, what is it subject to?
article8.answer: An additional tax equal to the difference between taxes paid and what would have been paid for the preceding three years.
options: A permanent increase in its tax rate.
An additional tax equal to the difference between taxes paid and what would have been paid for the preceding three years.
The forfeiture of the land to the state.
article8.reference: Sec. 1-d. ... (f) ...If designated land is subsequently diverted to a purpose other than that of agricultural use, or is sold, the land shall be subject to an additional tax. The additional tax shall equal the difference between taxes paid or payable, hereunder, and the amount of tax payable for the preceding three years had the land been otherwise assessed.

article8.question: What does Article 8, Section 1-e of the Texas Constitution prohibit?
article8.answer: The levying of State ad valorem taxes.
options: The levying of any income taxes.
The levying of any sales taxes.
The levying of State ad valorem taxes.
The levying of any occupation taxes.
article8.reference: Sec. 1-e. STATE AD VALOREM TAXES PROHIBITED. No State ad valorem taxes shall be levied upon any property within this State.

article8.question: To promote economic development, goods and merchandise are exempt from ad valorem taxation if they are detained in the state for certain purposes and transported out of state no later than how many days?
article8.answer: 175 days (or a later date established by the local governing body).
options: 175 days (or a later date established by the local governing body).
article8.reference: Sec. 1-j. ...if: ... (3) the property is transported outside of this State not later than: (A) 175 days after the date the person acquired or imported the property in this State; or (B) if applicable, a later date established by the governing body...

article8.question: Which of the following is listed as property that the Legislature may exempt from taxation by general laws under Section 2?
article8.answer: Actual places of religious worship.
options: The personal residences of government officials.
article8.reference: Sec. 2. EXEMPTIONS FROM AD VALOREM TAXATION. (a) ...the legislature may, by general laws, exempt from taxation public property used for public purposes; actual places of religious worship...

article8.question: A disabled veteran with a disability rating of 70 percent or more is entitled to a property tax exemption of up to what value?
article8.reference: Sec. 2. ... (b) ...A veteran who has a disability rating of 70 percent or more... may be granted an exemption from taxation for property valued at up to $12,000.

article8.question: According to Article 8, Section 3, taxes shall be levied and collected for what purposes only?
article8.answer: For public purposes only.
options: For state and county purposes only.
For any purpose approved by the Legislature.
To pay the salaries of government employees.
article8.reference: Sec. 3. TAXATION BY GENERAL LAW FOR PUBLIC PURPOSES. Taxes shall be levied and collected by general laws and for public purposes only.

article8.question: What is the maximum duration for which an appropriation of money can be made by the Legislature?
article8.answer: Two years.
article8.reference: Sec. 6. WITHDRAWAL OF MONEY FROM TREASURY; DURATION OF APPROPRIATION. ...nor shall any appropriation of money be made for a longer term than two years.

article8.question: What does Article 8, Section 7 prohibit the Legislature from doing?
article8.answer: Borrowing from or diverting any special fund from its purpose.
options: Cutting funding for any established program.
Borrowing from or diverting any special fund from its purpose.
article8.reference: Sec. 7. BORROWING, WITHHOLDING, OR DIVERTING SPECIAL FUNDS PROHIBITED. The Legislature shall not have power to borrow, or in any manner divert from its purpose, any special fund that may, or ought to, come into the Treasury...

article8.question: Under Section 7-a, net revenues from motor vehicle registration fees and taxes on motor fuels shall be used for what sole purpose?
article8.answer: Acquiring rights-of-way, constructing, maintaining, and policing public roadways.
options: Paying for general state government operations.
Acquiring rights-of-way, constructing, maintaining, and policing public roadways.
Supporting the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department.
article8.reference: Sec. 7-a. ...all net revenues... shall be used for the sole purpose of acquiring rights-of-way, constructing, maintaining, and policing such public roadways, and for the administration of such laws as may be prescribed by the Legislature pertaining to the supervision of traffic and safety on such roads...

article8.question: How is the rolling stock of railroad companies assessed for tax purposes?
article8.answer: In gross in the county where the principal office of the company is located.
options: It is exempt from county taxes.
Each rail car is assessed individually in the county where it is found.
In gross in the county where the principal office of the company is located.
It is assessed by the State Comptroller's office.
article8.reference: Sec. 8. ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION OF TAXES ON PROPERTY OF RAILROAD COMPANIES. ... The rolling stock may be assessed in gross in the county where the principal office of the company is located...

article8.question: No county, city or town shall levy a tax rate in excess of what amount on the $100 valuation for general, permanent improvement, road, and jury fund purposes?
article8.answer: Eighty Cents (80)
article8.reference: Sec. 9. MAXIMUM COUNTY, CITY, AND TOWN TAX RATES... (a) No county, city or town shall levy a tax rate in excess of Eighty Cents (80) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100) valuation in any one (1) year for general fund, permanent improvement fund, road and bridge fund and jury fund purposes.

article8.question: When can the Legislature release the inhabitants of a county, city, or town from the payment of taxes?
article8.answer: In case of great public calamity, by a vote of two-thirds of each House.
options: If the area has experienced an economic downturn.
By a simple majority vote of the Legislature at any time.
In case of great public calamity, by a vote of two-thirds of each House.
article8.reference: Sec. 10. RELEASE FROM PAYMENT OF TAXES RESTRICTED. The Legislature shall have no power to release the inhabitants of... any county, city or town from the payment of taxes... unless in case of great public calamity in any such county, city or town, when such release may be made by a vote of two-thirds of each House of the Legislature.

article8.question: What right does the former owner of a residence homestead sold for unpaid taxes have?
article8.answer: The right to redeem the property within two years from the date of the filing of the Purchaser's Deed.
options: The right to buy the property back at market value.
No right to redeem the property once it is sold.
The right to redeem the property within six months.
The right to redeem the property within two years from the date of the filing of the Purchaser's Deed.
article8.reference: Sec. 13. SALES OF LANDS AND OTHER PROPERTY FOR UNPAID TAXES; REDEMPTION. ... (c) The former owner of a residence homestead... sold for unpaid taxes shall within two years from date of the filing for record of the Purchaser's Deed have the right to redeem the property...

article8.question: All property belonging to a delinquent taxpayer is liable to seizure and sale for the payment of what?
article8.answer: All taxes and penalties due.
options: Only the principal amount of the taxes due.
Only property taxes, not occupation taxes.
Only real property, not personal property.
article8.reference: Sec. 15. LIEN OF ASSESSMENT; SEIZURE AND SALE OF PROPERTY OF DELINQUENT TAXPAYER. ...and all property, both real and personal, belonging to any delinquent tax payer shall be liable to seizure and sale for the payment of all the taxes and penalties due by such delinquent...

article8.question: According to Section 18, the Legislature shall provide for a single appraisal of all property within what geographic area?
article8.answer: Within each county.
article8.reference: Sec. 18. EQUALIZATION OF PROPERTY VALUATIONS FOR TAXATION... (b) A single appraisal within each county of all property subject to ad valorem taxation by the county and all other taxing units located therein shall be provided by general law.

article8.question: What items are exempt from all taxation until otherwise directed by a two-thirds vote of the Legislature?
article8.answer: Farm products, livestock, and poultry in the hands of the producer.
options: Farm products, livestock, and poultry in the hands of the producer.
article8.reference: Sec. 19. EXEMPTION FROM TAXATION OF FARM PRODUCTS, LIVESTOCK, POULTRY, AND FAMILY SUPPLIES. Farm products, livestock, and poultry in the hands of the producer, and family supplies for home and farm use, are exempt from all taxation until otherwise directed by a two-thirds vote of all the members elect to both houses of the Legislature.

article8.question: No property in Texas shall ever be assessed for ad valorem taxes at a value greater than what?
article8.answer: Its fair cash market value.
article8.reference: Sec. 20. AD VALOREM TAXATION OF PROPERTY AT VALUE EXCEEDING FAIR CASH MARKET VALUE PROHIBITED... No property of any kind in this State shall ever be assessed for ad valorem taxes at a greater value than its fair cash market value...

article8.question: What is required before a political subdivision can increase the total amount of property taxes imposed from the preceding year?
article8.answer: It must give notice of its intent and hold a public hearing.
options: A majority vote of the qualified voters.
It must give notice of its intent and hold a public hearing.
A two-thirds vote of its governing body.
article8.reference: Sec. 21. INCREASE IN TOTAL AMOUNT OF PROPERTY TAXES IMPOSED PROHIBITED WITHOUT NOTICE AND HEARING... (a) ...the total amount of property taxes imposed by a political subdivision in any year may not exceed the total amount of property taxes imposed by that subdivision in the preceding year unless the governing body of the subdivision gives notice of its intent to consider an increase in taxes and holds a public hearing on the proposed increase...

article8.question: What restriction does Section 22 place on the rate of growth of appropriations from state tax revenues?
article8.answer: It shall not exceed the estimated rate of growth of the state's economy.
options: It cannot exceed the rate of inflation.
It cannot increase by more than 5% per biennium.
It shall not exceed the estimated rate of growth of the state's economy.
There are no restrictions on the rate of growth.
article8.reference: Sec. 22. RESTRICTION ON RATE OF GROWTH OF APPROPRIATIONS. (a) In no biennium shall the rate of growth of appropriations from state tax revenues not dedicated by this constitution exceed the estimated rate of growth of the state's economy.

article8.question: What type of tax is the legislature prohibited from imposing on the net incomes of individuals?
article8.answer: An individual income tax.
article8.reference: Sec. 24-a. INDIVIDUAL INCOME TAX PROHIBITED. The legislature may not impose a tax on the net incomes of individuals, including an individual's share of partnership and unincorporated association income.

article9.question: According to Article 9, Section 1, no new county shall be created with an area less than what size?
article9.reference: Sec. 1. CREATION AND MODIFICATION OF COUNTIES. ... (1) Within the territory of any county or counties, no new county shall be created with a less area than seven hundred square miles...

article9.question: A new county cannot be created so as to approach nearer than what distance to the county seat of any county from which it may be taken?
article9.reference: No new counties shall be created so as to approach nearer than twelve miles of the county seat of any county from which it may in whole or in part be taken.

article9.question: What vote is required in each House of the Legislature to create a new county with an area between seven hundred and nine hundred square miles?
article9.reference: Counties of a less area than nine hundred, but of seven hundred or more square miles, within counties now existing, may be created by a two-thirds vote of each House of the Legislature...

article9.question: What is required to detach a part of an existing county and attach it to another county?
article9.answer: A majority vote of the voters of both counties.
options: A two-thirds vote of the Legislature.
A petition signed by 10% of residents.
A majority vote of the voters of both counties.
article9.reference: (2) No part of any existing county shall be detached from it and attached to another existing county until the proposition for such change shall have been submitted...to a vote of the voters of both counties, and shall have received a majority of those voting on the question in each.

article9.question: Under Section 1-A, the Legislature may authorize the governing body of which counties to regulate motor vehicles on beaches?
article9.answer: Any county bordering on the Gulf of Mexico.
options: Any county with a public park.
Any county bordering on the Gulf of Mexico.
Only counties with a population over 1 million.
article9.reference: Sec. 1-A. AUTHORITY OF COASTAL COUNTIES TO REGULATE MOTOR VEHICLES AND LITTERING ON BEACHES. The Legislature may authorize the governing body of any county bordering on the Gulf of Mexico or the tidewater limits thereof to regulate and restrict the speed, parking and travel of motor vehicles on beaches...

article9.question: What vote is required to remove a county seat that is situated within five miles of the geographical center of the county?
article9.answer: A vote of two-thirds of all the voters voting on the subject.
options: A simple majority of the voters.
A vote of the Commissioners Court.
A vote of two-thirds of all the voters voting on the subject.
An order from a District Judge.
article9.reference: Sec. 2. REMOVAL OF COUNTY SEATS. ...no county seat situated within five miles of the geographical centre of the county shall be removed, except by a vote of two-thirds of all the voters voting on the subject.

article9.question: The Legislature may authorize the creation of county-wide Hospital Districts in counties having a population in excess of what number?
article9.reference: Sec. 4. COUNTY-WIDE HOSPITAL DISTRICTS IN CERTAIN LARGE COUNTIES. The Legislature may by law authorize the creation of county-wide Hospital Districts in counties having a population in excess of 190,000 and in Galveston County...

article9.question: What is the maximum tax rate a county-wide Hospital District under Section 4 may be authorized to levy?
article9.answer: Seventy-five cents ($0.75) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) valuation.
options: Ten cents ($0.10) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) valuation.
Twenty-five cents ($0.25) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) valuation.
Fifty cents ($0.50) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) valuation.
Seventy-five cents ($0.75) on the One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) valuation.
article9.reference: ...to levy a tax not to exceed seventy-five ($ .75) cents on the One Hundred ($100.00) Dollars valuation of all taxable property within such district...

article9.question: A Hospital District created under Section 4 must assume full responsibility for what?
article9.answer: Providing medical and hospital care to needy inhabitants of the county.
options: Operating the county's emergency ambulance service.
Providing health insurance to all county residents.
Providing medical and hospital care to needy inhabitants of the county.
Funding all medical research within the county.
article9.reference: ...provided further, that such Hospital District shall assume full responsibility for providing medical and hospital care to needy inhabitants of the county...

article9.question: Under Section 5, if a tax is authorized for a hospital district in Amarillo or Wichita County, what can other political subdivisions within that district NOT do?
article9.answer: Levy a tax for medical or hospital care for needy individuals.
options: Contract with the hospital district for services.
Levy a tax for medical or hospital care for needy individuals.
article9.reference: If such tax is authorized, no political subdivision or municipality within or having the same boundaries as the district may levy a tax for medical or hospital care for needy individuals, nor shall they maintain or erect hospital facilities...

article9.question: Under Section 8, the creation and levying of a tax for the Hospital District in Comanche County must be approved by what?
article9.answer: A majority vote of the participating resident qualified voters.
options: A two-thirds vote of the Commissioners Court.
A majority vote of the participating resident qualified voters.
A petition signed by 20% of residents.
article9.reference: If such District is created, it may be authorized to levy a tax... provided, however, no tax may be levied until approved by a majority vote of the participating resident qualified voters.

article9.question: According to Section 9, a hospital district created by special law requires public notice to the district for how long before the law can be passed?
article9.reference: Provided, however, that no district shall be created by special law except after thirty (30) days' public notice to the district affected...

article9.question: What process is afforded by statute for the dissolution of a hospital district?
article9.answer: Determining the desire of a majority of the qualified voters within the district to dissolve it.
options: A decision by the Commissioners Court.
The district automatically dissolves if it becomes insolvent.
Determining the desire of a majority of the qualified voters within the district to dissolve it.
article9.reference: The Legislature may also provide for the dissolution of hospital districts provided that a process is afforded by statute for: (1) determining the desire of a majority of the qualified voters within the district to dissolve it;

article9.question: Section 9A allows the legislature to determine what for a hospital district?
article9.answer: The health care services it is required to provide and the requirements a resident must meet to qualify.
options: The salaries of its board members.
The specific location of its facilities.
The maximum tax rate it can levy.
The health care services it is required to provide and the requirements a resident must meet to qualify.
article9.reference: Sec. 9A. HOSPITAL DISTRICTS: REGULATION OF HEALTH CARE SERVICES. The legislature by law may determine the health care services a hospital district is required to provide, the requirements a resident must meet to qualify for services, and any other relevant provisions necessary to regulate the provision of health care to residents.

article9.question: The Legislature may authorize the creation of Airport Authorities composed of what?
options: Only cities with a population over 50,000.
article9.reference: Sec. 12. AIRPORT AUTHORITIES. (a) The Legislature may by law provide for the creation, establishment, maintenance and operation of Airport Authorities composed of one or more counties...

article9.question: An election to create an Airport Authority is called upon petition of what percentage of qualified voters within the county?
article9.reference: Sec. 12. ... (c) The Legislature shall provide for the holding of an election in each county proposing the creation of an Authority to be called by the Commissioners Court... upon petition of five per cent (5%) of the qualified voters within the county or counties.

article9.question: Directors of an Airport Authority shall serve for a term not to exceed how many years?
article9.reference: Directors shall serve without compensation for a term fixed by the Legislature not to exceed six (6) years...

article9.question: What is the maximum tax an Airport Authority can be authorized to levy?
article9.answer: Seventy-Five Cents (75) per One Hundred Dollars ($100) assessed valuation.
options: Ten Cents (10) per One Hundred Dollars ($100) assessed valuation.
Twenty-Five Cents (25) per One Hundred Dollars ($100) assessed valuation.
Fifty Cents (50) per One Hundred Dollars ($100) assessed valuation.
Seventy-Five Cents (75) per One Hundred Dollars ($100) assessed valuation.
article9.reference: ...the tax to be levied not to exceed Seventy-Five Cents (75) per One Hundred Dollars ($100) assessed valuation of the property.

article9.question: What does Section 13 clarify regarding the responsibilities of a newly created hospital district?
article9.answer: The district shall not be required to assume full responsibility for mental health or public health services.
options: The district must assume responsibility for all health services in its boundaries.
The district is prohibited from providing mental health services.
The district shall not be required to assume full responsibility for mental health or public health services.
The district must create its own public health department.
article9.reference: Sec. 13. ...the Legislature in providing for the creation... of a hospital district, shall not be required to provide that such district shall assume full responsibility for the establishment, maintenance, support, or operation of mental health services or mental retardation services...

article9.question: What may each county in the State provide for its indigent and poor inhabitants, according to Section 14?
article9.answer: A Manual Labor Poor House and Farm.
options: A Manual Labor Poor House and Farm.
article9.reference: Sec. 14. COUNTY FACILITIES FOR INDIGENT INHABITANTS. Each county in the State may provide... a Manual Labor Poor House and Farm, for taking care of, managing, employing and supplying the wants of its indigent and poor inhabitants.

article10.question: According to Article 10, Section 2 of the Texas Constitution, what are railroads constructed in the state declared to be?
article10.answer: Public highways, and railroad companies as common carriers.
options: The sole property of the State of Texas.
Public highways, and railroad companies as common carriers.
article10.reference: Sec. 2. RAILROADS AS PUBLIC HIGHWAYS AND COMMON CARRIERS; REGULATION. Railroads heretofore constructed or which may hereafter be constructed in this state are hereby declared public highways, and railroad companies, common carriers.

article10.question: What power does the Legislature have regarding railroad, freight, and passenger tariffs?
article10.answer: To pass laws to regulate them.
options: To set the exact price for all tariffs.
To pass laws to regulate them.
To delegate all tariff authority to the railroad companies.
article10.reference: The Legislature shall pass laws to regulate railroad, freight and passenger tariffs...

article10.question: For what purpose does the Legislature regulate freight and passenger tariffs on railroads?
article10.answer: To correct abuses and prevent unjust discrimination and extortion.
options: To ensure maximum profit for the railroad companies.
To correct abuses and prevent unjust discrimination and extortion.
To simplify the shipping process for consumers.
article10.reference: ...to correct abuses and prevent unjust discrimination and extortion in the rates of freight and passenger tariffs on the different railroads in this state...

article10.question: How is the Legislature directed to enforce the laws regulating railroad tariffs?
options: Through direct negotiations with railroad companies.
By creating a new court system.
article10.reference: ...and enforce the same by adequate penalties; and to the further accomplishment of these objects and purposes, may provide and establish all requisite means and agencies invested with such powers as may be deemed adequate and advisable.

article11.question: According to Article 11, Section 1, what are the several Counties of this State recognized as?
article11.reference: Sec. 1. COUNTIES AS LEGAL SUBDIVISIONS. The several Counties of this State are hereby recognized as legal subdivisions of the State.

article11.question: What does Article 11, Section 3 prohibit a county or city from doing?
article11.answer: Becoming a subscriber to the capital of any private corporation or loaning its credit to one.
options: Entering into contracts with other government entities.
Becoming a subscriber to the capital of any private corporation or loaning its credit to one.
Investing its funds in government bonds.
article11.reference: Sec. 3. COUNTY OR MUNICIPAL INVESTMENT IN OR DONATION OR LOAN TO PRIVATE CORPORATION OR ASSOCIATION PROHIBITED. No county, city, or other municipal corporation shall hereafter become a subscriber to the capital of any private corporation or association, or make any appropriation or donation to the same, or in anywise loan its credit...

article11.question: Cities and towns with a population of 5,000 or less may be chartered by what means?
options: By a special act of the Legislature.
By a vote of the county commissioners court.
article11.reference: Sec. 4. CITIES AND TOWNS WITH POPULATION OF 5,000 OR LESS: CHARTERED BY GENERAL LAW... Cities and towns having a population of five thousand or less may be chartered alone by general law.

article11.question: For a city with a population of 5,000 or less, what is the maximum lawful tax rate for any one year?
article11.answer: One and one-half per cent of the taxable property.
options: One-half of one per cent of the taxable property.
One per cent of the taxable property.
One and one-half per cent of the taxable property.
Two and one-half per cent of the taxable property.
article11.reference: ...but no tax for any purpose shall ever be lawful for any one year which shall exceed one and one-half per cent of the taxable property of such city...

article11.question: A city with a population of more than 5,000 may adopt or amend its charter by what method?
article11.answer: A majority vote of the qualified voters of said city.
options: A two-thirds vote of the city council.
A majority vote of the qualified voters of said city.
A special act of the Legislature.
article11.reference: Sec. 5. CITIES OF MORE THAN 5,000 POPULATION: ADOPTION OR AMENDMENT OF CHARTERS... (a) Cities having more than five thousand (5000) inhabitants may, by a majority vote of the qualified voters of said city, at an election held for that purpose, adopt or amend their charters.

article11.question: For a city with a population over 5,000, what is the maximum lawful tax rate for any one year?
article11.answer: Two and one-half per cent of the taxable property.
options: One and one-half per cent of the taxable property.
Two per cent of the taxable property.
Two and one-half per cent of the taxable property.
Three per cent of the taxable property.
article11.reference: Said cities may levy, assess and collect such taxes as may be authorized by law or by their charters; but no tax for any purpose shall ever be lawful for any one year, which shall exceed two and one-half per cent. of the taxable property of such city...

article11.question: When a city creates a debt, what provision must it make at the same time?
article11.answer: Assess and collect annually a sufficient sum to pay the interest and create a sinking fund of at least two per cent.
options: Get approval from the State Comptroller.
Assess and collect annually a sufficient sum to pay the interest and create a sinking fund of at least two per cent.
Purchase insurance to cover the debt.
article11.reference: ...and no debt shall ever be created by any city, unless at the same time provision be made to assess and collect annually a sufficient sum to pay the interest thereon and creating a sinking fund of at least two per cent. thereon...

article11.question: How often can a city charter be altered, amended or repealed?
article11.answer: Not oftener than every two years.
options: Not oftener than every two years.
article11.reference: Furthermore, no city charter shall be altered, amended or repealed oftener than every two years.

article11.question: Counties and cities bordering the Gulf of Mexico are authorized to levy a tax for what specific purpose?
article11.answer: Construction of sea walls, breakwaters, or sanitary purposes.
options: Construction of sea walls, breakwaters, or sanitary purposes.
article11.reference: Sec. 7. COUNTIES AND CITIES ON GULF OF MEXICO; TAX FOR SEA WALLS, BREAKWATERS, AND SANITATION... (a) All counties and cities bordering on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico are hereby authorized... to levy and collect such tax for construction of sea walls, breakwaters, or sanitary purposes...

article11.question: Which of the following types of county or municipal property is exempt from forced sale and taxation?
article11.answer: Public buildings and the sites therefor, and Fire engines.
options: All property owned by a city, without exception.
Public buildings and the sites therefor, and Fire engines.
article11.reference: Sec. 9. COUNTY OR MUNICIPAL PROPERTY HELD FOR PUBLIC PURPOSE EXEMPT FROM FORCED SALE AND TAXATION. The property of counties, cities and towns, owned and held only for public purposes, such as public buildings and the sites therefor, Fire engines and the furniture thereof, and all property used, or intended for extinguishing fires... shall be exempt from forced sale and from taxation...

article11.question: A Home Rule City may provide for a term of office for its officers not to exceed how many years?
article11.reference: Sec. 11. TERM OF OFFICE EXCEEDING TWO YEARS IN HOME RULE AND GENERAL LAW CITIES... (a) A Home Rule City may provide by charter or charter amendment... for a longer term of office than two (2) years for its officers... but not to exceed four (4) years...

article11.question: According to Section 11, how must a vacancy on the governing body of a municipality be filled?
article11.answer: By majority vote of the qualified voters at a special election.
options: By appointment by the remaining members of the governing body.
By majority vote of the qualified voters at a special election.
The position remains vacant until the next general election.
article11.reference: Sec. 11. ... (c) Any vacancy or vacancies occurring on such governing body shall not be filled by appointment but must be filled by majority vote of the qualified voters at a special election called for such purpose...

article11.question: A city may expend public funds to replace sanitation sewer or water laterals on private property only if it is done in conjunction with what other work?
article11.answer: The replacement or relocation of the main sewer or water lines serving the property.
options: The replacement or relocation of the main sewer or water lines serving the property.
A request from the property owner.
The construction of a new public building.
article11.reference: Sec. 12. EXPENDITURES FOR RELOCATION OR REPLACEMENT OF SANITATION SEWER OR WATER LATERALS ON PRIVATE PROPERTY. The legislature by general law may authorize a city or town to expend public funds for the relocation or replacement of sanitation sewer laterals or water laterals on private property if the relocation or replacement is done in conjunction with or immediately following the replacement or relocation of sanitation sewer mains or water mains serving the property.

article11.question: When a city places a lien on private property for the cost of replacing laterals, the cost must be amortized over a period not to exceed what?
article11.reference: ...and must provide that the cost shall be assessed against the property with repayment by the property owner to be amortized over a period not to exceed five years...

article11.question: Article 11, Section 13 gives the Legislature the power to define for all purposes which functions of a municipality are to be considered what?
article11.reference: Sec. 13. CLASSIFICATION OF MUNICIPAL FUNCTIONS. (a) ...the legislature may by law define for all purposes those functions of a municipality that are to be considered governmental and those that are proprietary...

article12.question: According to Article 12, Section 1, by what method shall Private Corporations be created?
options: By special acts of the Legislature.
By executive order of the Governor.
By a direct vote of the people.
article12.reference: Sec. 1. CREATION OF PRIVATE CORPORATIONS BY GENERAL LAWS ONLY. No Private Corporation shall be created except by general laws.

article12.question: What shall the general laws enacted for the creation of Private Corporations provide for, according to Article 12, Section 2?
article12.answer: The adequate protection of the public and of the individual stockholders.
options: A minimum tax rate for the corporation.
The appointment of its officers by the state.
The adequate protection of the public and of the individual stockholders.
article12.reference: Sec. 2. GENERAL LAWS FOR CREATION OF PRIVATE CORPORATIONS AND PROTECTION OF PUBLIC AND STOCKHOLDERS. General laws shall be enacted providing for the creation of Private Corporations, and shall therein provide fully for the adequate protection of the public and of the individual stockholders.

article14.question: According to Article 14, Section 1, how many General Land Offices shall there be in the State?
options: As many as the Legislature deems necessary
article14.reference: Sec. 1. GENERAL LAND OFFICE. There shall be one General Land Office in the State...

article14.question: Where shall the General Land Office be located?
options: In the geographical center of the state
In a location determined by the Land Commissioner
article14.reference: There shall be one General Land Office in the State, which shall be at the Seat of Government...

article14.question: What is required to be registered at the General Land Office?
article14.answer: All Land Titles which have emanated or may hereafter emanate from the State.
options: All Land Titles which have emanated or may hereafter emanate from the State.
article14.reference: ...where all Land Titles which have emanated or may hereafter emanate from the State shall be registered, except those titles the registration of which may be prohibited by this Constitution.

article14.question: What is the duty of the Legislature regarding the General Land Office?
article14.answer: To make the Land Office self-sustaining.
options: To fund the office from general revenue.
To audit the office's records annually.
To make the Land Office self-sustaining.
article14.reference: It shall be the duty of the Legislature at the earliest practicable time to make the Land Office self sustaining...

article14.question: What may the Legislature establish from time to time as may be deemed necessary?
article14.reference: ...and from time to time the Legislature may establish such subordinate Offices as may be deemed necessary.

article15.question: According to Article 15, Section 1, where is the power of impeachment vested?
article15.reference: Sec. 1. IMPEACHMENT BY HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES. The power of impeachment shall be vested in the House of Representatives.

article15.question: Which body is responsible for trying the impeachment of the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, and Attorney General?
article15.reference: Sec. 2. TRIAL OF IMPEACHMENT OF CERTAIN OFFICERS BY SENATE. Impeachment of the Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, Commissioner of the General Land Office, Comptroller and the Judges of the Supreme Court, Court of Appeals and District Court shall be tried by the Senate.

article15.question: When the Senate is sitting as a Court of Impeachment, what is required for a person to be convicted?
article15.answer: The concurrence of two-thirds of the Senators present.
options: A simple majority of the Senators present.
A three-fifths vote of the Senators present.
A unanimous vote of the Senators present.
The concurrence of two-thirds of the Senators present.
article15.reference: Sec. 3. IMPARTIAL TRIAL BY SENATE; CONCURRENCE OF TWO-THIRDS REQUIRED. ...no person shall be convicted without the concurrence of two-thirds of the Senators present.

article15.question: According to Section 4, what is the maximum extent of the judgment in cases of impeachment?
article15.answer: Removal from office and disqualification from holding any office of honor, trust or profit under this State.
options: Removal from office and a fine not to exceed $10,000.
Imprisonment for a term not to exceed ten years.
Removal from office and disqualification from holding any office of honor, trust or profit under this State.
Censure and a formal reprimand only.
article15.reference: Sec. 4. JUDGMENT TO REMOVE AND DISQUALIFY; PUNISHMENT UNDER OTHER LAW PERMITTED. Judgement in cases of impeachment shall extend only to removal from office, and disqualification from holding any office of honor, trust or profit under this State.

article15.question: Is a party convicted on impeachment still subject to criminal proceedings for their actions?
article15.answer: Yes, they shall also be subject to indictment, trial and punishment according to law.
options: No, impeachment is the final judgment.
Yes, they shall also be subject to indictment, trial and punishment according to law.
Only if the offense was a felony.
Only if the Senate recommends further prosecution.
article15.reference: A. Party convicted on impeachment shall also be subject to indictment; trial and punishment according to law.

article15.question: What happens to officers against whom articles of impeachment may be preferred?
article15.answer: They shall be suspended from the exercise of the duties of their office.
options: They continue to perform their duties until a verdict is rendered.
They are placed on paid administrative leave.
They are immediately removed from office.
They shall be suspended from the exercise of the duties of their office.
article15.reference: Sec. 5. SUSPENSION PENDING IMPEACHMENT; PROVISIONAL APPOINTMENT. All officers against whom articles of impeachment may be preferred shall be suspended from the exercise of the duties of their office, during the pendency of such impeachment.

article15.question: Who has the power to make a provisional appointment to fill a vacancy created by the suspension of an officer pending impeachment?
options: The President pro tempore of the Senate.
The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.
article15.reference: The Governor may make a provisional appointment to fill the vacancy, occasioned by the suspension of an officer until the decision on the impeachment.

article15.question: Under Section 6, the Supreme Court has original jurisdiction to remove which officials?
article15.answer: Any Judge of the District Courts of the State.
options: Any elected official in the state.
Any Judge of the District Courts of the State.
article15.reference: Sec. 6. REMOVAL OF DISTRICT JUDGES BY SUPREME COURT. Any Judge of the District Courts of the State who is incompetent... may be removed by the Supreme Court.

article15.question: For the Supreme Court to remove a District Judge, a presentment must be made in writing upon the oaths of how many lawyers?
article15.reference: The Supreme Court shall have original jurisdiction to hear and determine the causes aforesaid when presented in writing upon the oaths taken before some Judge of a court of record of not less than ten lawyers, practicing in the courts held by such Judge...

article15.question: For officers whose mode of removal is not provided for in the Constitution, who is responsible for providing a method for their trial and removal?
article15.reference: Sec. 7. REMOVAL OF OFFICERS WHEN MODE NOT PROVIDED IN CONSTITUTION. The Legislature shall provide by law for the trial and removal from office of all officers of this State, the modes for which have not been provided in this Constitution.

article15.question: Judges of the Supreme Court, Court of Appeals, and District Courts can be removed by the Governor upon what action by the Legislature?
article15.answer: On the address of two-thirds of each House of the Legislature.
options: A simple majority vote of each House.
On the address of two-thirds of each House of the Legislature.
A recommendation from the Judiciary Committee.
article15.reference: Sec. 8. REMOVAL OF JUDGES BY GOVERNOR ON ADDRESS OF TWO-THIRDS OF EACH HOUSE OF LEGISLATURE. The Judges of the Supreme Court, Court of Appeals and District Courts, shall be removed by the Governor on the address of two-thirds of each House of the Legislature...

article15.question: Before a vote for removal of a judge by address of the Legislature can pass, what must be provided to the judge?
article15.answer: The cause for removal must be notified to the Judge, and he shall be admitted to a hearing in his own defense.
options: A chance to resign from office.
A written apology from the Legislature.
The cause for removal must be notified to the Judge, and he shall be admitted to a hearing in his own defense.
article15.reference: ...provided further, that the cause or causes shall be notified to the Judge so intended to be removed, and he shall be admitted to a hearing in his own defense before any vote for such address shall pass...

article15.question: In addition to other procedures, a governor who appoints an officer may remove that officer with what?
article15.answer: The advice and consent of two-thirds of the members of the senate present.
options: A simple majority vote of the senate.
The advice and consent of two-thirds of the members of the senate present.
A recommendation from the Attorney General.
article15.reference: Sec. 9. REMOVAL OF PUBLIC OFFICER BY APPOINTING GOVERNOR WITH ADVICE AND CONSENT OF SENATE. (a) In addition to the other procedures provided by law for removal of public officers, the governor who appoints an officer may remove the officer with the advice and consent of two-thirds of the members of the senate present.

article16.question: What must all elected and appointed officers do before they enter upon the duties of their offices?
article16.answer: Take the official Oath or Affirmation.
options: Take the official Oath or Affirmation.
article16.reference: Sec. 1. OFFICIAL OATH OF OFFICE. (a) All elected and appointed officers, before they enter upon the duties of their offices, shall take the following Oath or Affirmation...

article16.question: The official Oath of Office requires an officer to preserve, protect, and defend the Constitution and laws of what two entities?
article16.answer: The United States and of this State (Texas).
options: Their home county and the State of Texas.
The United States and of this State (Texas).
The office they hold and the agency they work for.
article16.reference: ...and will to the best of my ability preserve, protect, and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States and of this State, so help me God.

article16.question: In addition to the Oath of Office, what must all elected and appointed officers subscribe to?
article16.answer: A statement that they have not engaged in bribery to secure their office.
options: A pledge of allegiance to the Texas flag.
A statement of their political party affiliation.
A statement that they have not engaged in bribery to secure their office.
article16.reference: Sec. 1. ... (b) All elected or appointed officers, before taking the Oath or Affirmation... shall subscribe to the following statement: 'I,_____, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I have not directly or indirectly paid, offered, promised to pay, contributed, or promised to contribute any money or thing of value... for the giving or withholding of a vote at the election at which I was elected...'

article16.question: According to Article 16, Section 2, the Legislature shall make laws to exclude from office persons who have been convicted of what crimes?
article16.answer: Bribery, perjury, forgery, or other high crimes.
options: Bribery, perjury, forgery, or other high crimes.
Any Class A misdemeanor or higher.
article16.reference: Sec. 2. EXCLUSIONS FROM OFFICE FOR CONVICTION OF HIGH CRIMES. Laws shall be made to exclude from office persons who have been convicted of bribery, perjury, forgery, or other high crimes.

article16.question: What is the consequence for a person convicted of having given or offered a bribe to procure their election or appointment?
article16.answer: They shall be disqualified from holding any office of profit, or trust, in this State.
options: They must pay a fine to the state.
They are barred from voting for life.
They must serve a mandatory prison sentence.
They shall be disqualified from holding any office of profit, or trust, in this State.
article16.reference: Sec. 5. DISQUALIFICATION FROM OFFICE FOR GIVING OR OFFERING BRIBE. Every person shall be disqualified from holding any office of profit, or trust, in this State, who shall have been convicted of having given or offered a bribe to procure his election or appointment.

article16.question: Article 16, Section 6 prohibits the Legislature from making appropriations for what purposes?
article16.answer: Private or individual purposes.
options: Any purpose not approved by the Governor.
Purposes outside the state of Texas.
article16.reference: Sec. 6. APPROPRIATIONS FOR PRIVATE PURPOSES... (a) No appropriation for private or individual purposes shall be made, unless authorized by this Constitution.

article16.question: Under what circumstance does absence on business of the State or of the United States forfeit a residence once obtained?
article16.answer: It shall not forfeit a residence once obtained.
options: If the absence is longer than one year.
If the person establishes a home in another state.
It shall not forfeit a residence once obtained.
If the person votes in another state's election.
article16.reference: Sec. 9. NO FORFEITURE OF RESIDENCE BY ABSENCE ON PUBLIC BUSINESS. Absence on business of the State, or of the United States, shall not forfeit a residence once obtained, so as to deprive any one of the right of suffrage, or of being elected or appointed to any office...

article16.question: In the absence of legislation, what is the maximum rate of interest for all contracts?
article16.answer: Ten per centum (10%) per annum.
article16.reference: Sec. 11. USURY... in the absence of legislation fixing maximum rates of interest all contracts for a greater rate of interest than ten per centum (10%) per annum shall be deemed usurious...

article16.question: If no rate of interest is agreed upon in a contract, what rate shall the contract not exceed?
article16.answer: Six per centum (6%) per annum.
article16.reference: Sec. 11. USURY... provided, further, that in contracts where no rate of interest is agreed upon, the rate shall not exceed six per centum (6%) per annum.

article16.question: Who is ineligible to be a member of the Legislature or hold any office of profit or trust under this State?
article16.answer: A member of Congress, or a person holding office under the United States.
options: A person who is not a natural born citizen.
A former governor of another state.
A person who has declared bankruptcy.
A member of Congress, or a person holding office under the United States.
article16.reference: Sec. 12. INELIGIBILITY OF MEMBERS OF CONGRESS AND OFFICERS OF UNITED STATES OR FOREIGN POWER TO HOLD ANOTHER OFFICE. No member of Congress, nor person holding or exercising any office of profit or trust, under the United States... shall be eligible as a member of the Legislature, or hold or exercise any office of profit or trust under this State.

article16.question: What happens if a district or county officer fails to reside within their district or county?
article16.answer: They shall vacate the office so held.
options: They are subject to a fine.
They must receive permission from the Governor.
They are given a 90-day grace period to move.
They shall vacate the office so held.
article16.reference: Sec. 14. CIVIL OFFICERS; RESIDENCE; LOCATION OF OFFICES. All civil officers shall reside within the State; and all district or county officers within their districts or counties... and failure to comply with this condition shall vacate the office so held.

article16.question: Under Article 16, Section 15, what constitutes the separate property of a spouse?
article16.answer: All property owned or claimed before marriage, and that acquired afterward by gift, devise or descent.
options: Any property held in that spouse's name.
All property owned or claimed before marriage, and that acquired afterward by gift, devise or descent.
Half of all property acquired during the marriage.
article16.reference: Sec. 15. SEPARATE AND COMMUNITY PROPERTY OF SPOUSES. All property, both real and personal, of a spouse owned or claimed before marriage, and that acquired afterward by gift, devise or descent, shall be the separate property of that spouse...

article16.question: According to Section 17, how long shall all officers of the State continue to perform the duties of their offices?
article16.answer: Until their successors shall be duly qualified.
options: Until the last day of their designated term.
Until their successors shall be duly qualified.
For a period not to exceed 30 days after their term expires.
article16.reference: Sec. 17. SERVICE OF PUBLIC OFFICER PENDING QUALIFICATION OF SUCCESSOR. (a) Except as provided by Subsection (b) of this section, all officers of this State shall continue to perform the duties of their offices until their successors shall be duly qualified.

article16.question: The Legislature has the power to enact a Mixed Beverage Law regulating the sale of mixed alcoholic beverages on what basis?
article16.answer: A local option election basis.
options: A county-by-county basis as set by Commissioners Courts.
article16.reference: Sec. 20. REGULATION OF MIXED ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES... (a) The Legislature shall have the power to enact a Mixed Beverage Law regulating the sale of mixed alcoholic beverages on a local option election basis.

article16.question: According to Section 21, contracts for public printing and binding shall be given to whom?
article16.answer: The lowest responsible bidder.
options: Any company with a state contract.
article16.reference: Sec. 21. CONTRACTS FOR PUBLIC PRINTING AND BINDING... shall be performed under contract, to be given to the lowest responsible bidder...

article16.question: What protection is granted to current wages for personal service under Article 16, Section 28?
article16.answer: They shall never be subject to garnishment, with certain exceptions.
options: They can be garnished for any consumer debt.
They shall never be subject to garnishment, with certain exceptions.
Up to 50% of wages can be garnished.
They can only be garnished with a court order for any type of debt.
article16.reference: Sec. 28. GARNISHMENT OF WAGES. No current wages for personal service shall ever be subject to garnishment...

article16.question: What is an exception to the prohibition on garnishment of wages?
article16.answer: The enforcement of court-ordered child support payments.
options: The enforcement of court-ordered child support payments.
article16.reference: No current wages for personal service shall ever be subject to garnishment, except for the enforcement of court-ordered: (1) child support payments; or (2) spousal maintenance.

article16.question: The duration of all offices not fixed by the Constitution shall never exceed what term?
article16.answer: Two years.
article16.reference: Sec. 30. DURATION OF PUBLIC OFFICES... (a) The duration of all offices not fixed by this Constitution shall never exceed two years.

article16.question: According to Section 31, the Legislature may pass laws prescribing the qualifications of practitioners of medicine, but what shall never be given by law?
article16.answer: Preference to any school of medicine.
options: Preference to any school of medicine.
article16.reference: Sec. 31. PRACTITIONERS OF MEDICINE. The Legislature may pass laws prescribing the qualifications of practitioners of medicine in this State, and to punish persons for mal-practice, but no preference shall ever be given by law to any schools of medicine.

article16.question: Who shall have a lien upon the buildings and articles made or repaired by them for the value of their labor or material?
article16.answer: Mechanics, artisans and material men.
options: Any employee of a construction company.
Only those who have a written contract.
article16.reference: Sec. 37. LIENS OF MECHANICS, ARTISANS, AND MATERIAL MEN. Mechanics, artisans and material men, of every class, shall have a lien upon the buildings and articles made or repaired by them for the value of their labor done thereon, or material furnished therefor...

article16.question: What is the general rule under Section 40 regarding a person holding public office?
article16.answer: No person shall hold or exercise at the same time, more than one civil office of emolument.
options: A person can hold up to three offices simultaneously.
A person can hold both a state and a federal office.
No person shall hold or exercise at the same time, more than one civil office of emolument.
There are no restrictions on holding multiple offices.
article16.reference: Sec. 40. HOLDING MORE THAN ONE PUBLIC OFFICE; EXCEPTIONS... (a) No person shall hold or exercise at the same time, more than one civil office of emolument, except that...

article16.question: Which of the following is an exception to the rule against holding more than one public office?
article16.answer: A Justice of the Peace.
article16.reference: Sec. 40. ...except that of Justice of the Peace, County Commissioner, Notary Public and Postmaster, Officer of the National Guard...

article16.question: A person who offers or gives any money or thing of value to influence an executive or judicial officer in their public duties is guilty of what?
article16.answer: Bribery.
article16.reference: Sec. 41. BRIBERY AND SOLICITATION OR ACCEPTANCE OF BRIBES. Any person who shall, directly or indirectly, offer, give, or promise, any money or thing of value... to any executive or judicial officer or member of the legislature to influence him in the performance of any of his public or official duties, shall be guilty of bribery...

article16.question: The Texas Constitution requires the Legislature to protect from forced sale a certain portion of what?
article16.answer: The personal property of all heads of families and unmarried adults.
options: All property owned by a business.
The personal property of all heads of families and unmarried adults.
Any property subject to a federal tax lien.
article16.reference: Sec. 49. PROTECTION OF PERSONAL PROPERTY FROM FORCED SALE. The Legislature shall have power, and it shall be its duty, to protect by law from forced sale a certain portion of the personal property of all heads of families, and also of unmarried adults, male and female.

article16.question: For which of the following debts is the homestead NOT protected from forced sale?
article16.answer: The taxes due thereon.
options: A personal loan from a bank.
A judgment from a civil lawsuit.
article16.reference: Sec. 50. PROTECTION OF HOMESTEAD FROM FORCED OR UNAUTHORIZED SALE; EXCEPTIONS... (a) The homestead of a family, or of a single adult person, shall be... protected from forced sale, for the payment of all debts except for: ... (2) the taxes due thereon;

article16.question: A home equity loan is limited to a principal amount that, when added to all other liens, does not exceed what percentage of the homestead's fair market value?
article16.answer: 80 percent.
article16.reference: Sec. 50. ... (a)(6) an extension of credit that: ... (B) is of a principal amount that when added to the aggregate total of the outstanding principal balances of all other indebtedness secured by valid encumbrances of record against the homestead does not exceed 80 percent of the fair market value of the homestead...

article16.question: How long does an owner have to rescind a home equity loan after it is made, without penalty or charge?
article16.answer: Within three days.
options: There is no right of rescission.
article16.reference: Sec. 50. ... (a)(6)(Q)(viii) the owner of the homestead and any spouse of the owner may, within three days after the extension of credit is made, rescind the extension of credit without penalty or charge;

article16.question: A homestead not in a town or city shall consist of not more than how many acres?
article16.answer: Two hundred acres.
article16.reference: Sec. 51. SIZE OF HOMESTEAD; USES... The homestead, not in a town or city, shall consist of not more than two hundred acres of land, which may be in one or more parcels, with the improvements thereon...

article16.question: A homestead in a city, town, or village shall consist of a lot or contiguous lots amounting to not more than how many acres?
article16.answer: 10 acres.
article16.reference: Sec. 51. ...the homestead in a city, town or village, shall consist of lot or contiguous lots amounting to not more than 10 acres of land, together with any improvements on the land...

article16.question: According to Section 52, the homestead shall not be partitioned among the heirs of the deceased under what circumstance?
article16.answer: During the lifetime of the surviving husband or wife, or so long as the survivor may elect to use or occupy the same as a homestead.
options: For a period of one year after the death.
If the deceased has outstanding debts.
During the lifetime of the surviving husband or wife, or so long as the survivor may elect to use or occupy the same as a homestead.
Under any circumstances; it must be sold.
article16.reference: Sec. 52. DESCENT AND DISTRIBUTION OF HOMESTEAD; RESTRICTIONS ON PARTITION. ...it shall not be partitioned among the heirs of the deceased during the lifetime of the surviving husband or wife, or so long as the surviver may elect to use or occupy the same as a homestead...

article16.question: What does Article 16, Section 59 declare to be public rights and duties?
article16.answer: The conservation and development of all of the natural resources of this State.
options: The establishment of a state police force.
The conservation and development of all of the natural resources of this State.
article16.reference: Sec. 59. CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES... (a) The conservation and development of all of the natural resources of this State... are each and all hereby declared public rights and duties...

article17.question: According to Article 17, Section 1, who may propose amendments revising the Texas Constitution?
article17.reference: Sec. 1. PROPOSED AMENDMENTS; PUBLICATION; SUBMISSION TO VOTERS; ADOPTION. (a) The Legislature, at any regular session, or at any special session when the matter is included within the purposes for which the session is convened, may propose amendments revising the Constitution...

article17.question: What vote is required in each House of the Legislature for a constitutional amendment to be submitted to the voters?
article17.answer: A vote of two-thirds of all the members elected to each House.
options: A simple majority of the members present.
A three-fifths vote of all members elected.
A vote of two-thirds of all the members elected to each House.
article17.reference: The proposal for submission must be approved by a vote of two-thirds of all the members elected to each House, entered by yeas and nays on the journals.

article17.question: Who prepares the brief explanatory statement of the nature of a proposed amendment that appears on the ballot?
article17.reference: The explanatory statement shall be prepared by the Secretary of State and shall be approved by the Attorney General.

article17.question: Who must approve the explanatory statement of a proposed amendment before it is published?
options: The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.
article17.reference: The explanatory statement shall be prepared by the Secretary of State and shall be approved by the Attorney General.

article17.question: How many times must the explanatory statement and proposition for a constitutional amendment be published in newspapers?
article17.reference: A brief explanatory statement of the nature of a proposed amendment...shall be published twice in each newspaper in the State which meets requirements set by the Legislature...

article17.question: What is the duty of each county clerk regarding a proposed constitutional amendment?
article17.answer: To post a full and complete copy in a public place in the courthouse.
options: To mail a copy to every registered voter.
To publish it in the local newspaper.
To hold a public hearing on the amendment.
To post a full and complete copy in a public place in the courthouse.
article17.reference: The Secretary of State shall send a full and complete copy of the proposed amendment or amendments to each county clerk who shall post the same in a public place in the courthouse at least 30 days prior to the election on said amendment.

article17.question: When must the first newspaper notice of a proposed constitutional amendment be published?
article17.answer: Not more than 60 days nor less than 50 days before the date of the election.
options: At least 90 days before the election.
Not more than 60 days nor less than 50 days before the date of the election.
In the week immediately preceding the election.
article17.reference: The first notice shall be published not more than 60 days nor less than 50 days before the date of the election, and the second notice shall be published on the same day in the succeeding week.

article17.question: What is required for a proposed amendment to become a part of the Constitution after an election?
article17.answer: A majority of the votes cast must have been cast in favor of the amendment.
options: A two-thirds majority of the votes cast.
A majority vote in at least 75% of the counties.
A majority of the votes cast must have been cast in favor of the amendment.
The approval of the Governor after the election.
article17.reference: If it appears from the returns that a majority of the votes cast have been cast in favor of an amendment, it shall become a part of this Constitution...

article17.question: Who makes the final proclamation that an amendment has been adopted and is now part of the Constitution?
options: The Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.
article17.reference: ...it shall become a part of this Constitution, and proclamation thereof shall be made by the Governor.
